151414787.review:
Soma is an interesting journey that includes horror elements and philosophical questions which been combined into a captivating and thought-provoking experience. It takes you to a research facility at the bottom of the dark sea, so the atmosphere is very thick and you won't feel safe most of the time, thanks to an abundance of different enemy types that are going to hunt you down. You are not in possesion of any kind of weapon, so your only choice of survival is to run away and find a good spot to hide. This hide and seek gameplay will be your friend throughout the whole game, so don't expect any wild shootouts. 

The level and art design is also pretty good and will lead you through nearly pitch black and claustrophobic areas which are packed with findable memos of the once living inhabitants. These give you a better overview of what actually happened and how it all went down. Enviromental storytelling is also implemented in a very natural and fitting way and makes you want to explore all areas to get new informations. The ending definitely wasn't what i had expected and was pretty thought-provoking and even a little bit sad. I really liked the philosophical approach they were going for, which is a rather unique thing to find in a horror game. 

In conclusion, Soma is a very captivating title that mixes a lot of different and interesting ideas and the end result is a peerless experience for every player, even when you are normally not into the horror genre. 

Have fun!

150518582.review:
100%. SPOILER FREE SOMA
OVERALL RATING: 9.5/10
LENGTH: 8-12 hours
100% ACHIEVEMENT EASE: There isn’t any missable achievements. 
WORTH THE PRICE?: Worth full price.   
OVERALL: SOMA is a horror game based in a future unknown complex, with weird monsters, and a weirder storyline. The game had me questioning myself at every turn, both in story aspects, and wondering what was going to happen next, or where the next monster would be. This game had a phenomenal story, buildup, and ending. 

PROS: The environment is incredible, and there isn’t a thing I would change about it. I don’t want to spoil anything, so I will be vague. The spook in this game comes from the environment, it doesn’t rely on jumps scares. This game is truly scary. The monsters are both scary and fantastic. The best part of this game is the psychological horror, like having to walk past people desperately begging for help knowing you wont be back to do anything about it. Also, a small note but this games exploration is incredible. There is a ton of lore to come across. The game really promotes exploration but doesn’t punish you If you don’t explore. You can play the game how you want. I played on my steam deck, and it was a phenomenal experience. Twists and turns throughout the story, and for me, a completely unexpected ending!

CONS: Not very many cons I can think of, other than the controls, specifically the climbing can be kindof wonky. There is 1 or 2 spots where I was genuinely confused and had to use a guide, though this was probably of my own accord and not the games fault.

150404309.review:
Don't let the label "Sci-Fi Horror from the creators of Amnesia: The Dark Descent" deter you.  This is first and foremost a well written first-person narrative about "consciousness", what it is, and if it can carry over from one substance to another.  If that's the "story train" you want a ticket to ride on, the ocean floor setting with unknown horrors and great voice acting will be the sights and bumps along the way.

If you passionately are hesitant of another "amnesia-like" experience, lucky for you there's a "safe mode" you can select to help pummel past the "let's stealth around this heart pumping sequence and hopefully not die four or five or thirty times".  I have trouble leaning one way or the other on this.  This is nowhere close to the nerve frying experience of Amnesia:  The Dark Descent because the enemy encounters are very well paced, don't repeat themselves, and never interfere with story (think any Uncharted game's "big moments", the game wants to keep you alive AND still feel the stress). But, If you don't think or care that these moments add to the emotional impact of landing in horror story in the middle of the ocean, by all means, choose the "SAFE mode" and experience the story.  

I want to say more but I dare not spoil the story.... easily one of the top ten best games I've ever played.  You cannot go wrong with this one.

150391784.review:
Having finished the game just this week, I could honestly gush about it for quite some time about a lot of things. But one of the lingering thoughts I've had is about all of the choices you have in the game not necessarily presented as a text box. You're given tons of these paths completely seamlessly, and leading to what I consider its subtle genius... They all lead to squat. There's only one ending, one immutable and linear ending.

Obviously, we've come to expect that when a game presents us with a choice that they will at least try and make the game world react and change to that. A game is bad when it doesn't do that, and Soma found a way to subvert that. Its main theme is the classic Ship of Theseus thought experiment, a metaphysics of identity. The choices don't change anything in the game because why would they? Pathos-II has already gone to hell and smarter people than Simon have been unable to turn it around. It's already on the point of no return so why should you face consequences for anything you choose when none of these choices actually affect your end goal? Instead of those choices changing the game, these choices change you. Have you ever thought about the difference between sentience and sapience? Do you value a benign sentient being more than a neutral sapient one? Is your mind an algorithm that would react with the same situations if you weren't aware of it? Is that algorithm what we call our "soul"?

I know that all sounds like pretentious bullcrap of someone trying to sound smart, but I really admire the experience Soma gave me. It's not a game without its flaws, but it is a sort of a transforming experience that presents you with a question you hadn't gave thought at all, and manages to keep you interested enough to not dismiss it. Soma commited one of the greatest crimes in game design in filling a game with choices that lead to nowhere and got away with it, I can't help but admire the quality of a writing being able to manipulate me like that.

Wow, simplemente wow.

SOMA es una auténtica maravilla. Ya había jugado anteriormente al Amnesia, de los mismos creadores, pero este juego le da mil vueltas. He pasado auténtico terror durante gran parte del juego hasta el punto en que he tenido que acabarlo a plazos porque no podía pasarlo de una, ya que me ponía de los nervios cada dos por tres. El terror está muy conseguido, haciendo que lo pases mal durante gran parte del juego y no con simples screamers como hacen algunos videojuegos y la gran mayoría de películas de "terror" actuales. 
Amo la ambientación, tanto en los interiores como en los exteriores, está muy muy muy bien hecha, ya sea por lo bonito que pueda ser el sitio o por el estrés que pueda causar en ciertas situaciones. Y la historia y los personajes me han parecido fantásticos, algunas cosas las veía venir de lejos y otras me han pillado por sorpresa, pero es toda muy disfrutable.

En resumen, un increíble juego de terror del bueno, con una ambientación y una historia geniales.
Fractional Games, os superasteis con SOMA.

150049501.review:
Note: this is my second copy of this game. My first playthrough was on PS4 6 years ago. I just finished a second playthrough today.

This is unequivocally one of my favorite games of all time let alone one of my favorite horror games. The way that it weaves its story is unparalleled and the questions that said storyline poses will stay with you for the rest of your life. This game gave me an existential crisis that I still think about to this day. 

I will not post spoilers because I believe this is a game best enjoyed blind. That being said, fans of horror and/or sci-fi NEED to experience the story at least once. 

The game is very narrative driven and has a few sections where you have to stealth your way past enemies. Every enemy has a different way to get past them and the challenge comes from finding out how to do this. There are some hints on each one throughout the narrative, but doing each encounter flawlessly is the real challenge. If you don't like the idea of this and just want to experience the story, there is also a safe mode that removes all damage and the consequence of death.

There are also plenty of puzzles that are very engaging but there were one or two that genuinely stumped me and I had to look up a guide.

The achievements in this game are all story based so if you care about those, you don't have to stress out about them at all. I would just sit back and enjoy what the game has to offer.

Overall, I would definitely recommend this to anyone but prepare to be changed along your journey. This is a story that needs to be experienced and not watched.

149962753.review: Of all the frictional games I’ve played (amnesia: the dark descent, amnesia: machine for pigs, amnesia rebirth) this is by far my favorite. I usually tend to lean away from heavily sci-fi based games so the amount of love I have for this game says a lot about how awesome it is. The graphics are great, the atmosphere and feel of the facility and the underwater environments are amazing and surprisingly believable. The monsters are all disturbing, scary and unpredictable. I haven’t even gotten to the story, which is great. It’s deep, intriguing and makes you think without being convoluted. This game will have you questioning yourself and leave you wondering what you would do or think if you were in this situation. Overall, this is as great a sci-fi story as it is a horror story. It’s rare that a game hits me on an emotional level but this one definitely did so I applaud the developers for doing something unique and refreshing, while also being emotionally investing. If you’re into first person survival horror, this is a must play. Even if you’re not a horror fan, but into sci-fi, I’d recommend this.

149928805.review:
Una vez pasado el juego ni una vez se menciona el nombre de SOMA, pero luego descubrí que se trata de una palabra griega que significa "cuerpo", sin contar con el alma. Y prácticamente de eso va SOMA. De salvar nuestro cuerpo. Durante un reconocimiento médico, Simons se despierta desorientado en lo que viene siendo una estación submarina abandonada, pero el peligro acecha en cada esquina... Todo el personal ha muerto, y lo que venía siendo un proyecto secreto para salvar a la humanidad depende únicamente de nosotros.

SOMA tiene las mismas mecánicas de los Amnesia (lanzamiento de sillas) y nos deja a sus anchas para que con nuestro ingenio podamos abrirnos paso a través de la estación submarina y el fondo oceánico para revelar los misterios de por qué estamos allí y qué ha pasado con todo. Un juego cuya historia no te esperas, y mucho menos el final (ojo con los postcréditos), pero acaba siendo redondo. 

[h1]8/10[/h1] Además la dosis de miedo me parece muy buena. La ambientación es brutal y los monstruos, aunque acojonan, no es en plan que te quedas atascado mucho tiempo sin saber qué hacer o que te asustas demasiado. 149746086.review:
Wow, just wow. I bought this game because I had heard it was good, but I knew next to nothing about it. I was just in it for some fun horror vibes and a good ride. I had no idea just how incredible this game actually would be.

If you haven't played it before or watched a let's play, go in blind, I implore you. Knowing little made every turn in the story and every important beat that much more impactful to me. The story is so good and engaging; it balances incredibly complex sci-fi concepts with genuine, emotional roots so well. I felt very connected to the characters and their plight.

The art direction and the level design is exemplary, and some of this game's most effective scares come simply from the vastness of its levels. You are alone and you are small and you feel so isolated by everything around you; it builds that sense of dread so effectively. It makes you cling to whatever tiny strands of remaining life and humanity you can find. 

The plot also proposes so many interesting, deep questions about the nature of existence which will stick with me for a long time. It presents so many conflicting ideas about what is and isn't a valid form of life, or what can even be considered "living". The characters don't ever reach any consensus opinion on these topics, and you the player will be confronted with a number of choices related directly to these concepts. What is it to be alive? To what lengths are you willing to go to preserve that sense of being?

SOMA is both an effective horror game and a spectacular sci-fi narrative. If you even have a passing interest in either of those genres, I could not recommend this game to you any more. It is absolutely worth your time.

149455444.review:
I really liked the dystopian scenario shown in SOMA. I haven't played the other games of Frictional Games so I can't make any comparisons but I felt like the developers did a really good job of creating this grim atmosphere and believably conveying the grief and desperation the people within the PATHOS-II complex must've felt after the catastrophe happened.

During my playthrough I was fine with the controls behavior most of the time but sometimes when you screwed up and have to run it doesn't feel smooth enough to me. Also vaulting isn't a thing which i found to be a bit disappointing since it would've been more immersive to just jump over the railing instead of searching for stairs.

The levels were designed thoughtfully and most of the time everything looked pretty realistic and not only purposely built to guide the player through the level. You could find thoroughly placed information in every room which would tell you more about your environment and the people who passed through or lived there which really added to the atmosphere.
Sadly some of the level designers slept in physics lessons or didn't feel like following certain physics rules.
The drag under water oftenly wasn't respected and there was one situation where you had to pass through strong currents which created huge amounts of dust clouds passing by the player but the player themself is able to jump without being torn away. They can also walk through these current without holding on to sth even though water has way more pulling force than wind for example. 
I wish minor details like these were respected during game design because it really crippled my immersion in that moment which is sad because most of the time this game is really great and definetly has a unique touch to it.

It took me some good 8 hours to beat the game (the rest is idle time during breaks).


4/5 stars 
I recommend this game despite my critizism and only to hard-scifi fans I would give a warning that some
obvious minor mistakes were made which might impact your experience but if you can ignore them like me, this game will give you a blast and question your perspective on life.

149409029.review:
Interesting, insightful, atmospheric, intelligent... just not much fun to play, nor am I certain this had to be told in the medium of video games.

GOOD STUFF:
+ What everyone cites: it presents a lot of salient points on personhood, life, and sentience. Just like the reality of the matter, they're not good questions if you're seeking concrete answers, but great ones to expand your thinking.
+ The storytelling was very well paced, going mixing up the orders of events and eventually bringing them back altogether for the beats and conclusion. Well-placed information across terminals and logs to give you a picture of events at each station.
+ A good gradient of thematic grayness that'll have everyone reserving their own opinions on the game's presented philosophies. 
+ Environments are incredibly detailed, especially for 2015. A little samey with the visuals, but usually a few new vistas at each checkpoint.
+ Sound design is superb. Music suits the game very well.
+ Mostly intriguing characters and converging plot lines. 
+ Puzzles were pretty basic but usually intuitive and give the game a modicum of interactivity; I only had to look up a hint for one of them.
+ The "antagonist" force is both visually well designed and thematically evocative. 


DID NOT ENJOY:
- I'm not really sure why this had to be a "horror" game, and it often hampered the experience. The horror elements aren't frightening, often just really annoying and maybe slightly nerve-racking. They feel like "we're the Amnesia devs, so we need to put some monsters in what's essentially a walking sim, I guess." The worst example of this is after you find the prototype of the MacGuffin and there is a series of rooms and hallways where you need to find some items to progress. A creature stalks the halls, and the "gameplay" is just waiting for his pathing to work out to allow you to where you need to go. The most baffling part is there are audio logs here for environmental storytelling (audiologs you have to be stationary to listen to) and the creature can still chase and kill you... do you want me to listen to the story, or do you want me to run away from Slenderman? Certain horror games use the genre either as a cut and dry upfront scare-fest, or to convey something narratively... this game doesn't really do either. 
Yes, there is a "Safe Mode" difficulty to avoid this aspect of the game, which makes me wonder why they bothered in the first place.

- The main character seems naive beyond the necessity for a fish out of water character; it takes me out of the story how accepting he is of his mind-bending situation and his agreeability in helping out the other character. He does get better as it goes on, though. 

- There is a DoF setting that can't be fully disabled. I was looking up how to disable it, and came across several posters recommending you leave it on for the atmosphere... but I fail to see what they were seeing. Persistent minor annoyance. 

- Movement is generally pretty sluggish, which can particularly be annoying when traversing long stretches of nothing or having to flee monsters. Some of the physics objects like panels and valves are really finicky to interact with. Again, notably egregious when you're being chased. 

- I don't feel the MacGuffin itself was explored nearly enough. You find out pretty early on in the story about a plain of living different to our own; I would have liked to see them get much further into how the human mind would adapt to this "reality," if it even could at all.

- Interactivity is kept pretty bare to the point I'm not sure this needed to be a game; combat doesn't exist, the puzzles are mostly trivial, navigation is pretty linear, the "avoid the monster" sections are mostly just crouch-walking and waiting, and the medium of interacting with the game is not meaningfully utilized to convey the story... Think, a story about artificial existence and personhood... don't you think you could utilize the medium of gaming for some meta narrative? They didn't. SOMA's best aspects could have easily stood as a book or movie in my opinion. At the very least they could have hammered home the themes of free will by having what few "choices" you make matter or having more of them, but they never affect the game going forward. 


OVERALL:
I enjoyed experiencing SOMA's world, and its greatest strength is obviously its narrative. Unfortunately, I think I would have basically gotten the same effect from watching a video playthrough of the game. I don't think any of its brilliance is lost by watching the game or playing it through in Safe Mode, especially since it omitted the opportunity of player choice which would have been a perfect pairing for this type of game.

149401019.review:
Atmospheric and well written, but not exactly perfect. SOMA tells a pretty original and thought-provoking story for those familiar with common sci-fi topics, with some very interesting and morally questionable actions for the player to ponder over. Overall I'd give the story an 8/10. The Horror aspect of the game will vary from person to person; I found the setting and overall atmosphere to be fittingly spooky but never quite felt scared at any point. Unfortunately the monster encounters aren't the best.

My particular gripes with the monster encounters is [spoiler]that they just aren't consequential. In the early game it's easy to just navigate around the few slow moving monsters around, but once you reach the Curie you'll find the first monster puzzle and every new encounter after that is pretty much the same concept. You lure the monster away or wait for their patrol to take them away from you, then navigate the long way around them to reach your objective[/spoiler]. I don't know if it was a bug or not, but it seemed like most of the monsters only reacted to seeing me, hearing me, or seeing my flashlight. Tossing objects around to draw their attention had no effect. In addition to the poor options you have for attracting the monsters' attention, [spoiler]I also found that death and injury were incredibly cheap. On more than one occasion I was killed by a monster, only to try again and find myself getting mauled 3 or 4 times with death seemingly no longer being a consequence. This may be a form of pity and is helpful for just pushing through sections, but the ultimate result was that I just brute forced my way through Tau station with little tact since the worst thing the monster could do to me was distort my sight[/spoiler]. The most thrilled I was at any point were in the chase sequences, navigating my way in the darkness after having memorized the turns and twists in the structure, but those were few and far between.

Definitely worth it for the story but YMMV for the gameplay.

149341318.review:
If you wanted more horror, existential dread and thalassophobia in your Bioshock 1 & 2 then brother do I have the game for you. 

For a Horror game, I was honestly expecting SOMA to feature more horror moments or at least more difficult encounters. It's alright at what it does,  the first hour of the game kept me on the edge of my seat as I was unaccustomed to the audio cues and where/what was a monster. However this wore off after a while as it gets easier to learn which areas are obviously monster infested and which aren't. Some monsters are honestly quite tame and can be followed behind at a short distance. However I feel SOMA uses horror and Monsters to enrich and add flavour to the other two areas of the game

The exploration and ambience, being truly alone in the bottom of the sea, surrounded by darkness is depressing and frightening. Approaching a new building comes with a short introduction puzzle, a way to gather some new information about upcoming areas and lore tidbits, the structures look like part of the ocean, covered in barnacles, rust and seaweed they can barely stay functional. Monsters lurk the tight and narrow hallways inside. The open areas started to honestly feel more safer, despite getting deeper, darker and more dangerous as the game goes on.
 The final section of the game [spoiler] where you struggle to see a few metres in front of you is a different story however. I absolutely loved the swap of the buildings became the safe areas between being chased by massive deep sea creatures [/spoiler]. 

You truly feel alone, the only other coherent voice being that of catherine, your pocket pal that can only speak when you upload her to a buildings console, and usually has little empathy or care for anything other than her project: The ARK and how to get you closer to this objective. Others encountered along the way are delirious, confused or vague.

For the 8 ish hours I played the game I felt so eerily alone, and every quiet moment was spent in my thoughts thinking about the different ideas and questions the game presents and what I think of them. The game gives you a survey about halfway through asking your thoughts on very spoilery questions, and then asks you them again at the very end. I didnt think my mind had changed a whole lot by the end. I'm a pretty stubborn guy, but even I was answering differently than I did about 3 hours ago.

Try not to spoil yourself, get it and revel in the games mysteries and enjoy it!

149099334.review:
For its sale price, it's a very engaging little adventure. I think it played its hand too early, and the "psychological horror" aspect to it is overblown (not really scary, more just suspenseful - though you can find shooters, like the Metro series, equally as atmospheric, and at least they have gameplay that isn't a walking sim). Some of the puzzles are annoying to get through, and it's not uncommon to get lost figuring out what pipe you forgot to hover your mouse over in a corner of a random room to progress to the next area.

Bit of a depressing game, too. Story-telling is okay, protagonist is revealed to have a pretty fatal flaw toward the end but nothing gets done with it.

Soft recommend, only if you're looking for a game similar to Amnesia. If all you're looking for is a singleplayer game to sp00k yourself, pick up something like F.E.A.R. or the first Metro game. Similar sp00ks, similar (sale) price, but at least in those you get to shoot shit.

149098566.review:
[h1] LA BELLEZA DETRAS DE UN MUNDO DISTÓPICO? [/h1]

En SOMA, nos ponemos en el piel de Simon Jarrett, un hombre que despierta en unas instalaciones submarinas aparentemente abandonadas llamadas PATHOS-II. A medida que exploras este oscuro entorno, te das cuenta de que algo terrible ha sucedido y que la línea entre lo humano y lo mecánico es extremadamente delgada.

Uno de los aspectos más destacados del juego es su atmósfera intensa y claustrofóbica. Los entornos submarinos, junto con los sonidos caracteristicos de un mundo sumido en la soledad, acompañado de una la iluminación tenue, contribuyen a una sensación de constante tensión. El juego utiliza el miedo de manera efectiva, manteniéndote activo a medida que te enfrentas a tus propios "miedos"

En términos de jugabilidad, se centra en la exploración, la resolución de acertijos y la evasión de enemigos (A lo Outlast, correr y esconderse). Aunque no es un juego de acción, la necesidad de tomar decisiones y resolver problemas agrega una capa adicional de inmersión a la experiencia.

Otro de los aspectos más destacados, o incluso diria que el mejor de todos; es la filosofía detrás del titulo, ya que plantea la noción de que la vida es algo preciado, incluso cuando se encuentra en formas inusuales o sufrientes. A lo largo del juego, nos vamos a encontrar con seres que luchan por sobrevivir en condiciones inhumanas, y esto, personalmente, te hace cuestionar QUÉ SIGNIFICA REALMENTE "ESTAR VIVO", como si nos desafiara a considerar si, incluso en sus formas más extrañas y dolorosas, la vida merece protección y compasión. Nos sumerge en dilemas éticos profundos y te obliga a reflexionar sobre la compasión, la empatía y la naturaleza misma de la vida. Estas cuestiones filosóficas se entrelazan muy bien con la trama y añaden una capa adicional de profundidad y significado a la experiencia, convirtiendo en una obra de arte que no solo asusta, sino que también provoca una profunda reflexión.

SOMA es un juego que combina con maestría el terror psicológico con una narrativa profunda y provocadora. Su enfoque en cuestiones filosóficas y existenciales lo hace destacar entre otros juegos de terror. Si te gustan los juegos que desafían tu mente y te hacen reflexionar mientras te asustan, entonces SOMA es una elección excelente.

149092489.review:
This would be a case of "so-so recommended" for me. If you REALLY enjoy horror games, it could be a great experience. Otherwise, the game's weaknesses become more and more obvious as you advance through the story.  

Others have said it: it's basically a (rather long) walking simulator with some "avoid-the-invincible-monster" moments sprinkled throughout. The story, worldbuilding and overall mood are fantastic, but the monster-escaping segments get extremely tedious around mid-game, due to confusing levels coupled with unfair enemy AI and intense visual distortion when you look at them (although you can turn that off to some extent). The [spoiler] electromagnetic teleporting zombie chasing you through an underwater shipwreck[/spoiler] is very frustrating and will mark the end of my playthrough. 

The other portions of the game give you interesting lore but are essentially devoid of any meaningful game mechanics. You will open doors, interact with computer screens and take/drop objects for no reason. That's about it. 

So it's one of those games I've restarted three times over the years, really wanting to like it! I'm now halfway through, dying to the same monster over and over, and I can't even change to "Safe mode" to enjoy the story without restarting the whole thing for a fourth time! That will be it for me, as I've played many horror games (here and on GOG) and I'm getting really tired of these "unbeatable-monster" clichés. If there were other fun mechanics, or at the very least a basic map to help you through, I might think about enduring this for another 5+ hours for the sake of storytelling. But no.

TL;DR: If you are an absolute fan of horror games and unstoppable enemies, you will probably love this. Otherwise, it might get boring or frustrating fast.

a game that leans more towards quiet dread and moody atmosphere than straight-up scares. a good display for frictional's sense of narrative design, showcasing full confidence in the base characters and concepts of their stories to carry them through, avoiding a lot of the cheaper ass pulls you'll often see worse horror games attempt to pull out a cheap bit of shock.

149001549.review:
Soma is like that existential crisis you never knew you needed. Ever wondered what would happen if your toaster started pondering the meaning of life while trying to kill you? Well, welcome to Soma.

This game is a philosophical rollercoaster that's more "What does it mean to be human?" than "Where's the exit?" You'll meet sentient robots, question your own sanity, and realize that even in the future, printers are still possessed by demons.

It's the kind of game that makes you reevaluate your life choices while avoiding creepy mechanical monsters. If you've ever thought, "I'd love a side of existential dread with my gaming," Soma is your five-course meal.

In a nutshell, Soma is the game that makes you confront your own mortality, all while desperately searching for the nearest flashlight to ward off your technological nightmares. Enjoy the ride, and remember to unplug your appliances before bed.

148945974.review:
[h2]Psychosoma, [i]qu’est-ce que c’est[/i]?[/h2]

[i]Amnesia: The Dark Descent[/i] made sure no talk of video game horror could go along without the mention of Frictional Games—the terrible, downright evil studio that not only dared deliver yet another horror game that completely lacked combat, but one that was so good and infectious that its stylings shaped the genre for almost a decade.

While we’ll probably never glimpse the terrible truth and come to an agreement on whether horror needs to opt out of combat entirely to be scary, Frictional’s follow-up title, [i]SOMA[/i], made a compelling argument that its exclusion is sometimes the only way of having your message heard. Unobscured by the whirls of revved-up chainsaws and the flashes of plasma cutters, it can still shine down there, in the quiet and the dark.

For [i]SOMA[/i], however, it’s not just important to hear what it has to say, but also how it says it. For a true barotraumatic dive into its thematic depths, take a look at the full version of [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/drugoja/recommended/282140/]this[/url] review, written by the ever-curious [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/40848670-Drugoja-In-The-Dreaming/]Drugoja in the Dreaming[/url]. Be warned that it will spoil all there is to spoil, so stick with me if you’ve yet to play the game.

[h3]Love the Body[/h3]

“Play one Frictional title, and you’ve played them all!” would probably be the adage, if not for [i]SOMA[/i]. As far as mechanical complexity is concerned, it’s as stripped back as Frictional’s ever been, serving as a natural progression and iteration of the team’s formula: take away more and more of the player's ability to outright remove the frights in their path and force them to deal with them without using force. In theory, this creates a feeling of helplessness not found in traditional survival horror and primes the player to engage with what’s on the screen in a different, less rigid, mechanically-minded way. The world becomes this real, unfamiliar place, where interactivity isn’t geared towards stuffing your backpack or blasting away at limbs and heads. Yet, remove one challenge of game development by taking an entirely different approach, and another will present itself—and if there’s something that Frictional didn’t learn from [i]The Dark Descent[/i], then they for sure had a cautionary tale in [i]A Machine for Pigs[/i].

For one, [i]The Dark Descent[/i] still had enough resource management to be viewed as nothing more than a clockwork interaction between its mechanics if you were so inclined. Tracing back up from and down again into Daniel’s insanity spiral was never explicitly obscured by it, but the game stopped short of blending the two together. There were glimpses of it, but the need for health bars, depletable light sources, and meters to manage prevailed in the end—this is a video game, after all, a [b]survival[/b] horror one, and something tells me Frictional wanted players to look a bit more beyond that.

The Chinese Room realised this and rid their sequel of tinderboxes and laudanum bottles, but instead of having the player use this newly freed-up attention on something important, they thought a separate window with a thesaurus would do just fine.

[i]SOMA[/i] is a horror game with puzzle elements, in which you attempt to escape a haywire, underwater facility on the floor of the Atlantic Ocean. Threats lurk about, even if combat is absent. Physical contact between you and these monsters amounts to getting flung across the room and some spooky screen effects should it end fatally. Running, sneaking and puzzling your way out of danger remains the way of getting out of trouble, and an intricate plot backed by heartfelt character drama and eerily genuine voice acting guides you from one setpiece to the next.

It’s a dance Frictional knows well; one that [i]SOMA[/i] comes so close to perfecting, were it not for the obvious criticism that’s been repeated since the very beginning with games of its ilk—it’s not scary. Rather, it’s frustrating and distracts from what’s more important. Any point at which whatever’s chasing you manages to remove those last few bits from your health bar is an almost pointless, immersion-breaking yank that pulls you out of the game. Indeed, an element solely there to make the video game more like a video game is what works against it the most. How’s that for a doozy?

[h3]Fear the Mind[/h3]

Horror is a bit afraid to entirely remove the fear of death. [i]SOMA[/i] has a Story difficulty, yet it is a band-aid “fix” to a fundamental design issue. If a tangible threat is what was needed, why not make the very environment something to be afraid of? If the goal was having interactions that are more inspired by the story and setting, rather than the mechanics, why undermine it? I’m sure making the airlock an enemy, by giving it the ability to crush you to a pulp should you miss the warnings on the wall to your left, would have done wonders for making players pay attention and interact with their surroundings in a more natural way. The bottom of the ocean is a scary place, period, no sci-fi monsters needed. Almost as scary as the idea of beefing up the HPL Engine is to Frictional, I’d imagine, to a point where that kind of interactivity would be possible without squinting at blurry textures.

But, even with engine limitations, Frictional’s art and sound direction are exceptional. It is why [i]SOMA’s[/i] rendition of the ocean floor is so inviting to get lost in and explore, even if it’s quite linear and teeters on the edge of falling into the motions of other games like it. But that begs the question: where does [i]SOMA[/i] break the mould?

Without having to worry about any kind of resource management, you’re free to direct your attention elsewhere. [i]SOMA’s[/i] monster encounters are a necessary evil with the way the game was designed; they suck, but can’t come close to ruining what’s so great about it. The puzzles are still there, of course, but the menial tasks of rerouting the power to the correct junction or finding the proper keycard can’t compare to the puzzle the game’s been built around.

[i]SOMA’s[/i] key themes, the dash of player choice there is, and the very plot are all interwoven with such great care and subtlety that they’d make a seamstress blush. The closer the game got to anything that’d obstruct it, the bigger my lament. In a roundabout way, It goes so far that it makes the lack of combat in [i]The Dark Descent[/i] seem like an oversight. Its narrative aspirations were never as grand, so laying further into traditional survival horror couldn’t have taken much out of it.

The morality of [i]SOMA[/i] is in the background, ready to creep up on you while your brain works away at the bits it presents. A "throwaway" line, a note on the wall, or an inconspicuous press of some button—it’s all towards a carefully constructed threefold message: whether ominous, hopeful, or just another pondering of whether androids dream of electric sheep, depends on you. No dialogue wheel, no alignment system, or distracting inventories; just you, some annoying monsters, movable boxes, and a choice that informs a different kind of fear. 

Sans those annoying monsters, it’s the otherwise thorough departure from survival horror that allows [i]SOMA[/i] to be filled with substance. All the frights—and everything else the game will make you feel—are in its world and the allegory it serves to paint. The psychological horror they’ve been talking about all these years; something a lot of developers have tried. Many may have succeeded, but a lot more missed what the focus should be and the design decisions at play to sharpen it up.

[quote][url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/41449676/]An international group of passionate writers and veteran reviewers, [b]Summit Reviews[/b] aims to deliver ethical, professional, and in-depth critique across Steam and beyond.[/url][/quote]

148597760.review: Horror elements aside the main driving point for this game is its enticing narrative and its attempt to tackle the theme of existentialism and having the player actively ponder what it really means to be human. Game-play is very on brand for Frictional Games in that it plays just like "Amnesia: The Dark Descent". You explorer your environment while stealthy avoiding enemies who are actively looking for you. The graphics are fantastic even for today's standards and voice work is decent. The atmosphere looks like if H.R. Giger and James Cameron had a baby. All and all not a difficult game, my playtime was about 9 hours and only got knocked out by enemies twice. All 10 achievements are tied directly to progression so it leaves little for replay value. The story is phenomenal enough to say if you just don't have the time or the money to invest in this game then do yourself a favor and see if your favorite "Let's Play" Youtuber has done a play through. This is an experience that will stick with you.

148594983.review:
Soma is a masterclass in video game storytelling, but the game play is missing some elements that make it a truly great game. As an experience, though, it is top notch. If you like to play games late at night where you zone out and forget about things, then this one really serves its purpose. Some games you play for the game play, others for the experience. Soma, like games like Amnesia, also developed by Frictional Games, definitely falls in the latter category. 

If you like "hide and seek" type game play where you hide from enemies, I can't really say whether it's good or bad since I dislike these types of games. But the hiding and avoiding enemies only makes up around 10-15% of the game, the rest being slow environmental puddles and weird atmospheric storytelling. The game was at first off putting, but as you progress the details of the story make more sense, and the twist at the end is more unexpected since it seems like it's building to something completely different. 

The game at first seems a bit like the movie Total Recall, wherein someone goes in for a brain scan and ends up in a completely different world. But it kind of plays on that, while feeling like a Philip K. Dick story it doesn't really give off that vibe at the end. It reminds me the most of the recently released film by Brandon Chronenberg named "Infinity Pool." In fact I think the twist at the end of this game is better than that movie, which is strange because usually game plots are worse than film plots. But the whole idea is that if you are cloned, are you still yourself? What is actually carrying over as consciousness? They're existential questions and the game does a good job of exploring them precisely because the setting is so desolate. 

Even though the undersea atmosphere might feel a bit like Bioshock, the game play is much simpler. There is no combat in this game except for a brief moment where you tase a robot. But the entirety of humanity is dead and the player is trapped at the bottom of the sea. The fact that the humans are all clones in robotic suits makes it more disturbing and eerie. The ocean itself is totally desolate, and since you are playing as a robot, there are many times that you can actually walk on the seafloor, which is quite surreal. The environments are so detailed that it's nice to just wander around and notice things like crabs minding their own business on the seafloor. At the end you descend to the deepest part of the sea, and in one of the most surreal experiences I've had in a game, you have to use little lighted guideposts to navigate the waters while heavy ocean currents obscure your view in the pitch black ocean.

Beyond that, the puzzles, if you want to call them that, aren't really hard, usually the only difficulty is figuring out where to go. There is a puzzle near the middle that's about ten steps long, and while not hard, it does take an hour or two of wandering aimlessly just to figure out what the steps are. The environment in this game is highly interactive. You can pick up just about anything, and the game makes it clear when an object is heavier so you have to drag it, like a ladder for example. Many of the simple puzzles involve manipulating switches and navigating screens. I actually enjoyed these, but I do wish they were a bit more difficult. Particularly near the end because the puzzles in the last sections of the game are barely nothing other than "pick this up here and put it over there."

The voice work is decent and the music is top notch. It's a highly cinematic experience, and a game that you really play for the experience more than anything else. Once you've completed it there's not really any reason to play it again, but it's such an impactful experience that it's still highly worth playing through one time. Yes it follows the route of a sci-fi cliche, but it does enough with it to make it still feel fresh and new. If it weren't for the obnoxious steal sequences where you die constantly for no reason I would say it's near perfect, but since those sequences are so annoying I am going to say it is a merely decent game but a fantastic overall experience.

148589076.review: Just a god damn great game. Fantastic. Makes me feel. Dang near made me shit my pants too. Fantastic combination.

148574448.review:
Incredible narrative - go in blind. Came for a Halloween scare, left with an existential crisis.  The deep sea setting is very well done. Puzzles aren't the hardest things in the world but are satisfying to put together. Navigating the areas is a joy just to take in everything.

Enemy encounters could have been better designed. I got cornered a few times where I'd get "hit" then respawn with an enemy standing directly over me/in front of a doorway, only to immediately grab me again and kill me. "Rules" regarding different enemy types could have also been more intuitive, a few felt like trial and error. Also saw one or two get stuck on geometry and neutralize themselves. All in all they're not too much of a hindrance and when they work they work well, but  they do stand out against the quality of the rest of the game (story/puzzles/design).

Overall highly recommended, not perfect but a game I'll be thinking about for a long time.

148505068.review:
What is the purpose of life? Is there an afterlife? What is morally correct and what's considered not being rational? What is reality after all? Can we truly trust our senses?

Imagine we make a copy of ourselves and we move it into a computer. That copy keeps all the memories we had in our life. That copy is technically able to think, but is it really that way? Could that copy be able to get to the conclusion that it's not the original one? Is it really feeling it, or is it just a very convincing simulation of feelings and it's only the result of a very complex algorithm? Could that copy fall into despair because of an existential crisis? These are just some of the vast amount of topics you will confront during this very short, but astonishing journey.

With a strong display of resonant nihilism, SOMA manages to go above and beyond expectations to stand out as one of the best horror games I ever played in my life and, in my opinion, it sets a standard not just for horror games as a genre, but for horror itself.

148367561.review:
"SOMA," developed by Frictional Games, stands as a testament to the studio's prowess in delivering an unforgettable and intellectually stimulating horror experience. Released in 2015, the game transcends traditional scare tactics, delving deep into philosophical inquiries, existential dilemmas, and the essence of consciousness. Its thought-provoking narrative and atmospheric design have cemented its position as a standout title in the horror gaming genre.

Set in an underwater research facility plagued by a catastrophic event, "SOMA" immerses players in a world brimming with existential dread and moral ambiguity. The game's narrative complexity is a standout feature, challenging players to ponder the nature of identity, consciousness, and the ethical implications of artificial intelligence. Through its gripping storyline, "SOMA" manages to evoke an emotional resonance that lingers long after the game's conclusion, prompting players to reflect on the fundamental questions that define human existence.

In addition to its profound narrative, "SOMA" excels in creating a hauntingly atmospheric environment. The dilapidated underwater facility, coupled with its unsettling ambient sounds and haunting soundtrack, sets the stage for a deeply immersive and psychologically intense experience. The game masterfully manipulates light, shadow, and sound to evoke a sense of pervasive unease, effectively heightening the emotional impact of its narrative twists and turns.

Gameplay-wise, "SOMA" strikes a delicate balance between exploration, puzzle-solving, and narrative progression. The puzzles are intelligently integrated into the game's environment, complementing the storyline and encouraging players to engage with the philosophical themes embedded within the game. While the emphasis on stealth and evasion may not cater to all players, it effectively contributes to the game's overall tension and suspense, fostering a sense of vulnerability that aligns with the game's overarching themes.

Furthermore, the game's non-combative approach to horror sets it apart from conventional survival horror titles, emphasizing psychological terror over jump scares or gratuitous violence. This intentional departure from typical horror game tropes allows "SOMA" to focus on delivering a more cerebral and emotionally resonant experience, appealing to players seeking a deeper, more intellectually engaging form of horror entertainment.

In summary, "SOMA" stands as a groundbreaking achievement in the horror gaming genre, offering a profound narrative experience that challenges players to confront the philosophical underpinnings of human consciousness and identity. With its atmospheric design, thought-provoking themes, and innovative gameplay mechanics, "SOMA" solidifies its position as a must-play title for those seeking a truly immersive, intellectually stimulating, and emotionally impactful gaming experience.

148260768.review:
Amnesia: the dark descent is what put Frictional Games into the mainstream but Soma is why I love them, simply put Soma is a masterpiece. 

Soma is not only one of the best horror games ever made it may be one of my favourite stories in any game, a truly disturbing exploration of self, an exploration of existential dread that will leave you questioning what is it to be human. This is a game that will stick with you for a long time and it will make you question what make you, you. 

Soma is a simple game, one all too familiar especially if you've played the amnesia games. You wake up in a strange place with no memories of how you got there, you are defenseless but you can interact with the environment and can manipulate the physics to complete puzzles and explore. There are dangers and your only options are to run or hide, all whilst finding clues as to how you ended up on the underwater base, PATHOS-II.

Like rebirth we have an incredibly chatty protagonist but unlike rebirth a large number of the games best moments come from the morally complex moments Simon finds himself in and the questions he has about his own morality, all the while he contemplates his concerns with the ambiguous Catherine, a companion who's no stranger to the circumstances they are faced with but isn't all she seems.

This game is absolutely dripping with atmosphere, whilst I possibly have a soft spot for games that take place in underwater bases that doesn't mean soma pulls it punches. The environments are bleak, left desolate not only by the goings on of it's underwater inhabitants but also by the sheer volume of water that weighs down on it. 

Puzzles are good, no moon logic required thankfully and enemy encounters whilst a bit annoying on repeat playthroughs (thankfully you can turn them off.) are scary and tense affairs with creatures that look genuinely disgusting and might be frictional games best monster designs yet.

I could go on and on about how incredible this gem of a game is but at the risk of spoilers please just play this game, horror fan or not this bleak tale needs to be experienced by all. Whilst there is always a glimer of hope this game will leave you sleepless with it's powerful thought provoking story. You will question yourself and you might find yourself wondering what is it about yourself that defines you, just don't crazy along the way.

148154548.review:
If only Soma had some Deus Ex DNA. 

I'm playing through Soma for the first time. The environments are great, the story is solid and well thought out, and the character dialog is natural and well performed. Unfortunately, I am really hating on the actual gameplay. The whole game is on rails like an antique text-based adventure game. There is only one solution to every obstacle, and only one path to moving forward. I understand this is Frictional's thing, but, for me, this is disempowering as a player, frustrating, and flat-out boring. If only Frictional had taken some inspiration from the Deus Ex games, and provided multiple solutions to obstacles, and multiple paths to move forward, both of which the player was free to discover and pursue as they saw fit, I think Soma would have been both more fun for all players and a timeless classic. As it is, Soma ends up being, in my opinion, just a prettier, better written, niche Frictional effort that that breaks no new ground and plods along the path set by the Penumbra games and Amnesia The Dark Descent.

147887853.review:
[h1] SOMA: A Philosophical Dive into Deep-sea Horror [/h1]

SOMA, the brainchild of Frictional Games, ventures into the realm of psychological horror, but it goes beyond the usual blood and gore. Instead, it delves into the depths of mental and emotional torment, tackling profound questions about consciousness, existence, and philosophical dilemmas. As I began my journey with SOMA, I anticipated a typical psychological horror experience, but what I discovered was a game that boldly explores the realm of philosophical horror.

While SOMA excels in some aspects, it sometimes struggles with its narrative delivery. At its best, it surpasses Frictional's previous work, The Dark Descent, in every way, offering a quintessential haunted house experience. At its weakest, it feels like a series of philosophical conversations you might overhear in a college bar after a screening of "The Matrix," grafted onto a game focused on escaping terrifying creatures and fixing malfunctioning computer systems.

The writing in SOMA fluctuates between excellent and forced. The game relentlessly fills every quiet moment with reflections on the unfolding events. The protagonist often prompts conversations that feel contrived, as if he's desperate to extract philosophical insights from his harrowing predicament. This overemphasis on philosophical musings occasionally tests the player's patience. However, when SOMA hits its stride, it delivers extraordinary moments that are deeply unsettling.

The overarching plot of SOMA is nothing short of magnificent. The game conceals far more than its pre-release marketing campaign revealed, including early surprises that would serve as climaxes in other games. While the narrative's delivery, predominantly through text and audio logs, occasionally feels labored, the game boasts moments of sheer brilliance. When SOMA truly embraces its philosophical horror roots, it creates an eerie and mesmerizing atmosphere.

SOMA is undeniably frightening. The grotesque creatures you encounter are nightmarish, shrouded in glitchy obscurity as they draw near. The disconcerting sounds they emit are chilling, enhancing the overall sense of dread. The game's audio design, aside from some out-of-place voice acting, is exemplary.

Furthermore, SOMA offers an exceptionally tactile experience. Frictional Games' titles have always excelled in environmental interactions, and SOMA is their masterpiece in this regard. The way doors and drawers open and close, objects are manipulated, and items are hurled across rooms creates a profound sense of immersion. The physicality of the game world is nothing short of remarkable.

SOMA pays homage to machinery, akin to Alien: Isolation. As you navigate the underwater facility, you'll encounter typical horror game tasks: repairing equipment and finding alternative routes through dilapidated laboratories and power stations. The satisfaction of these interactions contributes to the credibility of the world and ratchets up the tension when pursued by enemies.

However, the game's setting, while featuring intricate details, left me somewhat underwhelmed. While interior locations are well-constructed and feature clever deviations from the typical sci-fi facility design, the underwater sections felt like a chore. The initial awe quickly gave way to a desire to return to the more engaging interior environments. Additionally, the visual and mechanical similarity between the machine intelligence and other horrors in horror media felt uninspired.

SOMA undoubtedly stands as Frictional's most accomplished game to date. While it occasionally feels like listening to a friend who can't stop dissecting the philosophical implications of a horror film, the game effectively blends traditional first-person horror with thought-provoking themes. It managed to instill fear and provoke contemplation, yet it might not linger in my memory as long as some of my favorite horror games. Nevertheless, SOMA's sound design, immersive world, and moments of sheer terror make it a must-play for horror aficionados with a pull towards the philosophical.

A perfect example of weird fiction done at its very best, mixing themes of immortality, death, the end of the world, and asking fundamental questions about what it means to be human.

You spend most of the game confused and disoriented as fuck. Nothing makes sense, it's claustrophobic and anxiety inducing, and even the bits and pieces of story that you manage to piece together don't even come close to fully preparing you for the totality of the story, especially the ending, first time round.

A game I would 20 out of 10 recommend to anyone that enjoys this kind of existential horror experience. 

The ending is one of the best I have ever encountered in a game, hands down. 

Not much replay value admittedly, but more than makes up for that by being much, much more than worth just giving a go. This shit is bone chilling and gut wrenching in a way horror rarely manages these days.

Well, well worth the experience.

147697455.review:
This one reminds me a lot of Amnesia A Machine For Pigs. The game is absolutely fantastic in most aspects: visuals, sound, setting, atmosphere, art style, sound, acting, story (especially this one) etc etc, but it sort of struggles with the horror at least gameplay wise for me.

The enemies themselves are pretty neat in their design, well some are way better than others when it comes to being scary at least, but they are all absolutely fantastic when it comes to how they sound at least which may be enough for some. It has basically the same kind of fail state as Rebirth and perhaps slightly more forgiving than that one (the system itself is a neat idea but I do not think it works as well as it should), and I find that it kind of ruins the tension for me. This, and other reasons that I find hard to put into words, caused enemies to become just annoying obstacles instead of terrifying pursuers even at my first encounter and caused me to not even try to get away if I found it would take longer than just getting caught. 

The absolute scariest thing to me was just that it was really deep underwater and I have kind of a fear for the sea, but I do not think this was completely intended to be thie scariest thing in game (outside of the story). Sure there was indeed one underwater sequence in particular that made me feel kind off ill to my stomach with fear which I gotta hand to the devs: amazing job there at least lol. For me all the water stuff also managed it to feel way scarier than Rebirth (and also alot of other horror games, Frictionals included), but that may vary alot depending on how you handle that stuff. Though I have to give them that they at least kept the monsters more varied and less scripted feeling than Rebirth imo.

*And yes, I know that there are "story mode" difficulties which removes enemies, or at least death, for both Rebirth and this one, so yeah could have played that if I like the story that much. But having no threat at all would probably ruin the experience more for me so yeah*

But the biggest reason the enemies were so annoying to me was because of how they got in the way of me learning more about this incredible story (and not in a fun way which being scared would have like the underwater stuff), which is also pretty much the most horrifying thing in the game. It tackles some really big questions and some very heavy themes in such a fantastic way and I loved everything about it and how it kept asking me to come up with my own answers for these questions. I went in "completely" blind (basically only knowing it is under water and something something robots). The turns it took were very intriguing and it went in directions I was not really expecting. It also got pretty emotional at times and truly heartbreaking, especially towards the end, which I did not at all expect when starting the game and it really made me feel awful about a lot of stuff that happened (which I think is lovely lol). The story is truly a masterpiece and definitely the best they have written so far.

I find it a bit funny and interesting how two of the best stories I have ever experienced in a game have both come from Frictional and at the cost of the horror part not being that great (well, The Chinese Room is true for AMFP but ya know what I mean). Was not expecting much more beyond great horror when going through their games, but I am more than pleasantly surprised! Frictionals masterpiece and an absolute must if you enjoy horror and/or sci-fi stories, but also if you enjoy horror games of course.

147534635.review:
"SOMA" is a hauntingly brilliant masterpiece that transcends the boundaries of typical horror games, offering players an unforgettable journey into the depths of existential terror and philosophical introspection. Frictional Games has crafted a true work of art that not only terrifies but also challenges the very essence of human existence.

At its core, "SOMA" is a cerebral experience, taking players on a profound exploration of consciousness, identity, and the nature of humanity itself. The game's narrative is a tour de force, weaving a complex and thought-provoking story that stays with you long after the credits roll. It doesn't rely on cheap jump scares or gratuitous gore; instead, it presents a creeping, atmospheric dread that seeps into your psyche, leaving you with a lingering sense of existential unease.

The underwater world of PATHOS-II serves as the perfect setting for this cosmic horror tale. The dilapidated, decaying environments are meticulously detailed and utterly immersive. The juxtaposition of the eerie silence of the deep sea with the clanking machinery and eerie sounds of malfunctioning technology creates an atmosphere that is both unnerving and captivating.

Gameplay in "SOMA" strikes an ideal balance between puzzle-solving and survival horror elements. The scarcity of resources and the presence of relentless, nightmarish foes keep you on your toes without feeling overwhelmingly punishing. The puzzles are intelligently designed, serving as integral components of the narrative rather than mere obstacles.

One of the game's standout features is its impeccable voice acting and dialogue. The characters, particularly the protagonist, Simon Jarrett, are portrayed with depth and nuance. As players, we're drawn into their struggles and existential dilemmas, forming a deep emotional connection that enhances the overall impact of the story.

The philosophical questions raised throughout "SOMA" are nothing short of mind-boggling. The game invites players to ponder the nature of consciousness, the ethical implications of artificial intelligence, and the boundaries of human identity. It's a rare and welcome treat to find a horror game that challenges your intellect as much as it terrifies your soul.

In conclusion, "SOMA" is a triumph in both horror gaming and storytelling. Its cerebral, thought-provoking narrative, coupled with its eerie atmosphere and intelligent gameplay, make it a must-play for fans of the genre and anyone seeking a truly unforgettable gaming experience. This game not only scares you; it makes you question the very essence of what it means to be human.

147513684.review:
I enjoyed the game for the most part. It was fairly straight-forward. At it's core, it is just a survival horror game but it left me wanting more.

The game is devoid of any inventory, combat, unlockables, skill tree, etc. & the only progression within the game is walking (surviving) from one area to the next. The game has almost no NPC's & the few enemies I encountered I was unable to do anything more then sneak past them; no combat, no defensive items, no items to assist you whatsoever.

During my early progression within the game, I was quite amused that you could interact with nearly everything as well as open nearly every cabinet and drawer. However, this rarely served any purpose (as fore-mentioned that you have no inventory, so you could not collect any of these objects) and it often left me disappointed. 

It's not often we have a nearly complete underwater setting for nearly the entire game. The atmosphere is dark & you are alone. Very few games truly encapsulate the feeling of isolation as well as this one does. 

In conclusion, I did enjoy the game & would actively recommend it.

147399765.review:
SOMA turned out to be a really enjoyable adventure that exceeded my expectations.
The game starts out very unassuming, even too simplistic, giving the early impression that it's just going to be another of those walking sims with horror elements attached.  And THEN, all of a sudden, one's world gets turned on its head, launching you on a thought-provoking, futuristic adventure where the idea of being human and alive is rocked to its core.  What exactly IS life?  When exactly is something ALIVE?  What does it mean to be conscious?  Is the distinction between what is human and what is machine really all that clear?  And if faced with ultimate annihilation, the total destruction of humankind, is the prospect of becoming machine in order to survive really all that bad?
The player explores the environment, interacts with devices to solve puzzles and gain access to further areas, traversing the inside of buildings located deep underneath the ocean, also the seabed, coming into contact with strange creatures both human-like and not so human.  In some areas the main quest is to avoid these creatures, to get past them relying on your wits alone.
Slowly a picture emerges of the place, and the time, you find yourself in, of the life-and-death struggles the human crew went through, coming to terms with your fate, with mankind's fate.  Or do you?  Are you even real?  What is reality?
A truly mind-bending masterpiece.

147389635.review: The atmosphere and environmental vibes on this game are immaculate. You really do feel like you're alone, confused, and lost in an empty, dead, post-apocalyptic world - and usually when you realize you're NOT alone is when the horror settles in. The story was enjoyable and kept me hooked until the end, to find answers and finally learn what exactly happened, even if those answers ended up being pretty bleak and depressing. The game touches on themes of existentialism, what it means to be human, and whether continuing our consciousness through A.I. is stripping us of humanity or preserving it. You can learn even more of the story and lore by exploring and discovering environmental details, such as journal entries and data logs, to paint a fuller picture of what these people went through in their final days. Really fun game, even if I had to occasionally google what to do next!

147165158.review:
Cons: 

* Strongly recommend your first playthrough be on the easy route where you can't be killed by monsters, etc. as there will be some incredibly frustrating sections where you have to run from things and if you don't know the exact friggin' route (you won't), you will be caught and die...so be advised. This was very poor implementation by the developers - these instances should have at least involved the character monologuing to let the player know they need to figure out their route, or give them an idea of where to go when there's a chase sequence, etc. otherwise you just set them up to be infuriated by a death they couldn't have possibly predicted. 
* You have no way of fighting the monsters you encounter - some of the larger ones that are several times larger than yourself makes sense, but the ones that are about your size (which is the majority of them), it is absolutely nonsensical (and infuriating) that you can't pick up a blunt object and beat the ever living crap out of them - literally all you can do is try to run and hide which is impossible in certain sections as they'll coach you to hide in the dark and then even if you're crouched and moving slow the monster will, in many instances, still come right to you. 
* Absolutely detested the ending - I won't spoil anything but I thought it was a poor payoff for all the time invested. 

Pros:

* Solid graphics & good physics engine. 
* They do an excellent job creating a creepy environment. 
* Excellent sound effects to add to the creepy environment. 
* Interesting story to follow that keeps you engaged throughout the majority of the game. 

Game Length: ~12-15 hours

Final Rating: 5/10 - Not recommended. This game has a lot of good stuff, but more bad than good. I thought the story ended poorly for all the time and frustration you put in to get to the end. This was my first experience with a game from this developer and it will likely be my only one.

147023128.review:
This game is basically a best-in-genre sci-fi movie. It's full of philosophical quandaries regarding life, consciousness and existence. If you like these topics and have any critical thought at all, this game will have you reeling for days, possibly longer. I recommend exploring as much as possible (or as much as the monsters allow) so you can immerse yourself in the rich lore and backstory. There is so much to find that has nothing to do with the mandatory objective. The levels are very open, detailed and you can pick up and manipulate just about everything in them that's of a size a human could lift and handle (note: sometimes this can be confusing as to what is useful and what isn't, but you'll start to pick up on what is relevant and what is not -- they tend to 'shimmer' when you look at something relevant). There is very little guidance. I recommend foregoing guides as much as possible and try to figure everything out on your own. When I closed the guidance, I was much more immersed and also surprised at the scares. 

It's very easy to lose yourself in this title. The game is aging at this point, but still is beautiful and well-designed. One of the upsides of an older game is that any decent-spec'd modern machine should be able to render this in 1080p or higher with the graphic settings maxed, while still achieving a very playable FPS. I recommend turning all the settings up unless you have a really old or really low-spec machine. I played most of the game on a 2018 Precision laptop with a 4GB GPU and it still got 60+ FPS on maxed settings.  

Conclusion: 10/10 HIGHLY RECOMMENDED. Easily one of the best and most unique titles out there. This game is for anyone who is a fan of story-rich, first person sci-fi games that don't involve shooting guns and killing aliens. FYI, you have no weapons, only your cognizance.

146787743.review:
SOMA is a unique experience that will stay with you long after you've finished playing. The developers have created a truly dark and oppressive atmosphere in the abandoned underwater complex. The sense of danger lurking around every corner leaves your nerves tightened like strings.

Excellent sound design and intricately detailed locations fully immerse you into this nightmare. The game expertly balances action and exploration, never letting you relax for a minute. The puzzles are clever and seamlessly woven into the narrative.

But the most important part of SOMA is its philosophical component. The themes of transhumanism, consciousness transfer, and human nature make you think about things many people try not to ponder. The existential horror of the game penetrates deep into your mind.

SOMA is a masterpiece of psychological horror that will stick with you long after the credits roll. I will finish my review with a quote by Friedrich Nietzsche that perfectly captures the main idea of the game:
"He who fights with monsters should look to it that he himself does not become a monster. And if you gaze long into an abyss, the abyss also gazes into you."

And also from myself, Thomas Rendes:
"In our pursuit of immortality, we risk losing what makes us human. By transferring our minds into machines, we gain only the illusion of life without its true value. Better to be mortal than soulless."

One of the best games I've ever played and for the sheer power in the story alone. The gameplay especially the atmosphere is terrifying to boot and its pretty well made. The environment was what made me first fall in love with the game, the derelict post apocalyptic seascape of a world hooked up to a warped AI trying to sustain the dying embers of humanity. The atmosphere and world-building in this game is phenomenal to boot. But what sealed the deal and made this game one of my top favorites is easily the immensely profound story (how well the themes of identity is discussed) and the superb characters. By the end of the game, you can feel deeply for these characters for how well fleshed out they were (due to how well their VAs have brought them to life), even those you don't meet in person. The game makes you feel like you've been on this crazy journey from start to finish with a wonderful companion with endearingly human flaws by your side. Its ending has also been one of the most cathartic experiences I've ever felt in a game. Would I recommend playing this game? Without question.



(also goofy note: I spared everyone in the hopes post-game lonely Simon finds a way to regroup with survivors and fix the omnitool. I suppose its copium, but its proof that a game impacts you)

A Mind-Bending Dive into Existentialism and the Unknown - Soma Review

Soma, the brainchild of the visionary team at Frictional Games, is nothing short of a masterpiece that invites players to explore the deepest corners of existentialism and the unfathomable mysteries of the unknown. From its gripping narrative to its atmospheric world-building and thought-provoking themes, Soma is an experience that transcends the boundaries of traditional gaming.

One of the standout features of Soma is its profound exploration of existentialism. The game skillfully delves into the philosophical questions surrounding identity, consciousness, and the essence of self. As players navigate through the eerie underwater facility of PATHOS-II, they are confronted with choices and dilemmas that force them to grapple with the very essence of what it means to be human. Soma doesn't just pose these questions; it immerses players in them, creating an existential journey that leaves a lasting impact.

The game's narrative is a triumph of storytelling. From the moment you step into the shoes of Simon Jarrett, the protagonist, you're thrust into a world that is as mysterious as it is captivating. The narrative slowly unravels, revealing layers of complexity and moral ambiguity that keep you engaged from start to finish. It's a testament to the game's writing and direction that it manages to maintain an atmosphere of tension and dread while simultaneously encouraging players to reflect on profound philosophical themes.

The unknown looms large in Soma, and it's this element that makes the game truly unforgettable. As you explore the dark, claustrophobic corridors of PATHOS-II, you'll encounter bizarre and enigmatic creatures that challenge your understanding of reality. The game keeps you on edge, constantly questioning what is real and what is a product of your character's deteriorating mental state. The sense of existential dread and the fear of the unknown are palpable throughout, creating an atmosphere that is both unsettling and utterly compelling.

Visually, Soma is a work of art. The underwater setting is beautifully realized, with every detail meticulously crafted to immerse you in its hauntingly atmospheric world. The use of lighting and sound design is nothing short of masterful, enhancing the sense of unease and wonder as you venture deeper into the abyss.

Soma is a groundbreaking gaming experience that pushes the boundaries of what video games can achieve in terms of storytelling and thematic exploration. It challenges players to confront the fundamental questions of existence and the mysteries of the unknown, all within the framework of a gripping and haunting narrative. If you're looking for a game that will leave you pondering the nature of consciousness and the depths of the human psyche long after the credits roll, Soma is an absolute must-play. It's a testament to the power of interactive storytelling and a shining example of how video games can be a medium for profound philosophical exploration.

146149500.review:
Heartbreaking. Completely heartbreaking.

SOMA's story is intellectually satisfying, sure. But after you've done all the mental gymnastics to comprehend what has happened to Simon Jarrett and where (and what) he is by the end of the game...that's when your heart breaks for him.

Crrrack.

But crap. Then you realize it's not just Simon. It's all of us. The world is gone. All that's left are some data points floating through endless, dark space in some frigging tin can. Then your heart breaks for humanity.

Crrrack.

But not done yet. As the credits roll and you shut the game down to happily go about your life, you realize your heart is still breaking. Wait. What? 

Yeah, somehow—just like that damn structure gel—SOMA itself has leaked into real life. Sorry folks, but the reality is that we all die alone. Ultimately though, it's worse for Simon since he'll never die. [spoiler](Or, rather, he died long, long ago).[/spoiler] But he's still alone. Forever. Man, that sucks.

"Catherine? Please don't leave me alone..."

This is the kind of extremely rare narrative that, if I dwell on it too much, I might stop playing games altogether because it hurts too deep. too sharp, too dark.

Here in 2023, it's been 8 years since SOMA was released, which is when I originally played it. I've not since encountered a game's story that has affected me as much as the fate of poor, confused Simon, and the depressed but dogged crew of Pathos-II, and the rest of the world--in the game, and in real life. 

So yeah, like Simon, I'm still here...just waiting. Hmm. I guess I also lost the coin toss...

I'll start with the pro's:
- Story
- Voice acting

Con's:
- Gameplay
- Enemy AI
- Visuals

This game could be summarized as a point & click, walking simulator. There is no exploration, it's not a survival horror, so you do not need to look in every corner and open every locker. You can, but you'll find nothing and anything noteworthy will be in plain view. The puzzle's require no thought and can be brute forced. 
The enemy's are buggy, popping in view when rounding a corner and can spawn at either side of a hallway, boxing you in. if you do get hit, (and here's my main frustration) you get this horrible visual distortion effect. Which doesn't go away unless you pass this 'growth'. Which can take some time, giving you an unnecesarry headache.

These things completely took my out of the immersion of the game and ruined the experience. It's not a bad game, but a mediocre one. And I feel this game took some steps back from their great Amnesia games.
