145158531.review:
Coming off the heels of Amnesia: The Dark Descent, Frictional Games was in an precarious position. They created a horror masterpiece that exceeded sales expectations and launched the careers of some of the biggest names on Youtube. How do you top that? How do you create a game that not only pulls in the same audience, but redefines an entire genre? The answer is you can't, and Frictional Games knew that. Instead of trying to capture lightning in a bottle, they decided to create a horror game that is unrivaled by anything else to date.

SOMA is a game that takes horror to a different level. Instead of being Lovecraftian, SOMA goes with a sci-fi horror theme. In place of Gatherers you have various creatures that resemble machine monstrosities. Instead of a castle, you're cast into the deep blue and are forced to figured out what's going on. The dark corners of Brennenburg Castle are instead replaced by the wet, moldy halls of PATHOS-II.

Now the big question is did SOMA achieve the same heights as The Dark Descent? It depends on your perspective. From a purely traditional horror view, no, it did not. SOMA lessened the scares dramatically in favor of atmosphere. SOMA oozes atmosphere the first moment you step onto PATHOS-II. The lighting, sound design, and layout makes PATHOS-II feel like a real underwater facility, and the emptiness of it all adds to it. SOMA relies less on jumpscares and instead wants to immerse the player in an oppressive atmosphere where anything at any moment could result in doom.

So while SOMA is not as scary in the traditional sense, SOMA does excel at one thing and that is the story. SOMA's story is unlike else anything in horror games, or games in general. SOMA is a mirror. It is a mirror you gaze into and it stares right back at you until you feel absolute fear encasing your body. It is a game every person needs to play, especially in this day and age as technology continues to advance at levels we cannot comprehend. SOMA's story is Frictional Games' best story, period. Nothing can ever top what they managed to do with SOMA's story. It brings a whole new dimension to horror, and it is best you experience it on your own. 

Now does that mean the game lacks scares? Not at all, in fact some of the encounters are quite terrifying. Even in moments of stillness, SOMA does find a way to make you feel insecure, and make you scared of what could be lurking around the corner. Environmental story telling goes a long way, and SOMA's environment tells a very petrifying story, that feels real and reflective.

I wish I could say more about the game, but that would spoil the experience. The experience is best seen blind. Going into it without any knowledge is needed to get the biggest impact. When the credits rolled, I had to sit there and listen to the eerie song play as I reflected on all the questions SOMA asked me. Questions that I never thought I would be asked, and questions that made me think for days.

SOMA was not a commercial success for Frictional Games, and it is extremely unfortunate, because I think SOMA did manage to achieve the impossible: Make a game that is even better than Amnesia: The Dark Descent. While it was not as scary, its story, location, acting, and environment made it a journey that is completely unforgettable. But most importantly, its themes and the questions it asks you will stick with you for days or weeks, or in some cases, the rest of your life. SOMA is a horror game, just not in the way you are expecting but when it does show its unique take on horror, it is more terrifying than anything The Dark Descent presented.

Do yourself a favor and take the journey into PATHOS-II, and give Frictional Games the props they deserve for delivering a masterpiece. It is very rare for a horror game to strike fear into your heart, but Frictional Games pulled it off, and it is something you need to experience and reflect on. After all, SOMA is a mirror, and you should be terrified of what that mirror shows.

This game has genuinely one of the most interesting stories ever written. I couldn't help but watch hours upon hours of story analysis videos after finishing it. That's how interesting the whole story is.

It's definitely not for everyone, since a lot of people do not enjoy horror games. I'm cowardly too, but playing this from start to finish was really worth it, even after the immense feeling of dread I felt after finishing it.

You can see the story of Soma as a really depressing one, or as a story of hope, but the intense feelings of horror that the game will let you experience will let you to think mostly as the former. 
Death is a really important theme in this game, the whole story is shaped around it, the reason why the ark project started, the reason why the end of the game is devastating, and the reason why the Wau started all of the insanity that made the events of the game happen, death was what humanity wanted to stop, what they thought they solved with the ark, but life and death is a kind of knowledge that we would never be able to grasp completly.

145038902.review: A masterpiece. A rare horror game that keeps you terrified for its entire duration. Through incredible sound and environment design, as well as brilliant use of its various monster designs, the game never allows you to get comfortable. It is always upsetting. Furthermore it is wrapped up in one of the most existentially thought provoking and horrifying narratives conceived. I am a film guy, its my favorite medium, but SOMA may have highhandedly convinced me that video games are the best medium for the horror genre. I only have two real flaws with it. First, the underwater walking sections in the beginning are tedious, however this changes near the end during one of the most intense segments of the entire experience. Second, there is one section with monster that offered very little freedom to evade, causing me to have to reload multiple times. Challenge is not the issue here, rather with repeated tries the monster became much less scary, and the game lost some momentum. Nonetheless, SOMA is a game I could not recommend highly enough.

If you haven't played this and you want a classic horror title that still plays and looks great then SOMA is the game for you.

144677036.review:
This game is outstanding. The gameplay is simple enough, mainly exploring with some stealth and simple puzzles, but the atmosphere, narrative, excellent writing and performances are what makes it totally compelling to keep riveted to the end - revealing some fantastically deep questions that are handled superbly. Many games try to ask big questions and then over-simplify it with cheesy writing, unbelievable characters and/or forced gameplay. Soma does not fall into any of these traps. The questions it raises are powerful, and, and given enough gravity to keep you asking yourself them after the game is finished.

I'm going to play through this again on story mode, this time taking my time to understand every aspect of the world and characters that I encounter as there is a really rich narrative here that is only apparent when you take the time to piece everything together.

I truly treasure the experience that this game has given me. I hope you get to as well.

144656366.review:
[h1] Overall, I would recommend SOMA for someone who likes a story based game with little to no combat. [/h1]

This game was definitely not what I was expecting. I was looking for a game similar to Bioshock (my all-time fave), but apart from the underwater/machine elements, that's pretty much where the similarities end. 

A great game for story, but very little action. [u] You get no weapons or way of defense for yourself in this game. [/u] Instead, everything is stealth based. Because of this, I decided to play it on safe mode. In my opinion, if there's no way to defend yourself by fighting/beating enemies, then there's not really a point to them being able to kill you game-play wise. 

On safe mode, I enjoyed exploring all there was to find while not having to worry as much about dying. You still get that eerie/danger aspect, but are able to slow down and explore the story more. This also cut down on the amount of stealth that was required, which was nice considering there is a lot of time spent hiding and waiting in this game.

[b] Note: you can still die in safe mode; its just a lot harder. [/b]

144514316.review:
Take Bioshock, remove all the nostalgic flair by changing the setting from 1959 (plus a few decades of disrepair) to a cold and clammy 2104, remove the weapons, put in more outdoor seabed sections, add more realistic marine weathering details on exterior hulls, and you’ve got yourself SOMA. A “hide, or run away from unkillable monsters” type of true horror game very much like Amnesia, Alien Isolation and Penumbra. But with an interesting existential sci-fi take. However, the game’s pacing is all over the place. The beginning is very confusing. You are Simon Jarett, a Torontonian who for the past few weeks has been recovering from a severe car accident that claimed the life of his girlfriend and left him brain damaged. You begin the game in his apartment, scheduled for a brain scan conducted by two scientists holed up with their equipment in a construction site, probably to avoid reporting to the government which would impede their pace of research. They are experimenting on a new type of diagnostic method wherein they build a 3D model of a person’s brain obtained by a scan, to then safely go ahead and run all kinds of treatment simulations on the computer model before settling for the best one and then only applying it on the real brain, thereby minimizing damage to the real organ. But right after the scan, you suddenly wake up somewhere else. In a derelict base. You don’t know if the two scientists (of who only one was present during your appointment) have pulled a prank on you or not but it is getting scarier by the minute and you have to find a way out. Back to Toronto. Well, good luck chasing that past life…

The first few hours of the game are scary, disorienting, and you quickly find yourself having to evade mechanical monsters without even an inkling of where you are and whats going on. Maybe that was part of intentional game design, to cast you headlong into the new sci-fi dystopia? After that though, exposition begins to take form as you come across computer logs and audio flashbacks you can “access” by standing near corpses to witness tidbits of conversation from their final hours (not because of any superpowers, but because people have blackbox chips implanted into them), and finally a friendly voice that you try to meet up with. The research base in the game is divided into separate sectors very much like Doom 3. You begin in a hub called Upsilon, responsible for geothermal energy that powers the base. The voice you hear over the intercom tells you she is holed up in Lambda, and you need to take a train to get there. Sound familiar? Bioshock 2 had this train system too. 

A lot of the horror is lost and the mood suddenly changes when you come across machines that are… friendly. And disoriented. You feel sorry for them, because of who they think they still are. At least, you don’t feel so alone anymore like you did in the initial hour or two of gameplay. 

As you explore more of the base you learn that it is part of an underwater research complex called Pathos II officially tasked with studying marine biology but secretly building a space gun that could launch stuff from the bottom of the ocean into space using some kind of accelerator tube, and you find out this complex housed some 60 or so researchers who ended up being the only ones to survive an apocalyptic comet strike that made earth's surface utterly uninhabitable. Like waay worse than Last of Us or Fallout type of uninhabitable. So with extinction imminent, what is the last words you would normally say to a friend? “See you on the other side.” What if waking up on the other side were a real possibility rather than wishful thinking? And considering resources will eventually run out even in a base deep in the ocean that survived the initial impact, and considering repopulating earth is out of the question due to the level of devastation and small gene pool of survivors, one of the scientists, Catherine Chun, had the bright idea to scan people's minds, insert the virtual copies into a solar powered vessel called the ark and shoot it into space using the space gun, where they would live out eternity in a virtual reality simulation.

While youre busy wrapping your head around this, more moral quandries arise around the concept of digitizing something. For instance, these days when moving data over, we know two ways of doing it: ctrl+c to copy or ctrl+x to cut. This dilemma also persists in 2104. With cutting implying the deletion of the data at its place of origin. If you know what I mean. Mark Sarang is the most famous example of someone who thinks this way. He believes the only guarantee of consciousness transferring over to the digital side, is by terminating the being that it was copied from, at the moment of copying. Otherwise all you would do is create a duplicate – a new you that isnt the real you. But if the real you ceases to exist at the moment of transfer, there would only be this one you left from this moment on, hence, the only real you left in the universe. He manages to convince Robin Bass and a few others of this continuity belief system, and they follow his example until the ARK program is put on hold to prevent further crew member suicides.

Over the course of the game, you end up having to face the consequences of not listening to Mark Sarang: duplication. The first one could be avoided because the original expired rather quickly and technology wasnt advanced enough to put the scan into use without many decades passing. The second time however, is when you have to make choices. The third time however...when there is no choice to be made...well...keeps you up at night thinking who is real.

I guess Futility is the game's main theme. Simon’s brain scan is futile – it doesn’t help him and he only lives on for 1 more month. Simon 2’s journey from Upsilon to Omicron is futile – with the DUNBAT gone & no other Haimatsu Power suit available, he never reaches the Ark in Tau & is left behind in Omicron. And Simon 3, while launching the ark into space, gets left behind in Phi. But was really everything futile? Simon 1’s brain scan allowed one sane entity to awaken in Pathos 2 and save Catherine 2. Catherine 1’s brain scan allowed Catherine 2 to stop Simon 2 from going insane & give his new life purpose, which was putting Simon 3 into the power suit. And Simon 3 launched the Ark into space, giving those in the sim hundreds, if not thousands more years.

Of course, whatever interest you pick up in the story is quickly drowned by having to evade monster, after monster, after monster. See those fancy terminals during midgame? Cant read what they say cause there's a monster patroling nearby and reading from a computer screen happens in real time so the game isnt frozen and those footsteps are getting louder... It really gets frustrating and annoying after a while. And desensitizes you to the horror genre because there's just so many of them. That's the horrid third quarter of the game. Where your new friend Catherine is once again in your pocket and you have nobody to talk to, just a "get to that part of the facility next" sort of vague general instruction but of course, you dont know where youre headed and the halls are increasingly darker and gorier. It gets so bad that I found myself looking up the Soma Walkthrough because I didnt know what to do next. Not talking about the puzzle parts in safe areas mind you, they are very easy, but sometimes things like having to update the security clearance on an ID card to access an elevator, or having to remove a high voltage safety panel to access the circuitry inside. Things that are hidden in plain sight. Near monsters. Ugh. And run (without the possibility of reaching a safe spot like holing up in a locker or something) like a headless chicken until you get whacked and have to limp to the nearest single-use healing mollusc, or hide among blood and corpses waiting for misshapen monsters to disgustingly shuffle past. Not my idea of fun.

144472013.review:
This is one of those games where the actual game play is the weakest element, and its strengths come from the atmosphere, narrative, and audiovisual experience. This is not a game that seeks to a fun and engaging game above all else.

Going further into the game play, the game will mostly consist of hiding from monsters and outmaneuvering/outsmarting them (otherwise known as stealth), and even though it is the weakest part of the game, there are some solid game play sequences throughout the game. The stronger stealth sections happen when the enemies have a significant weakness to them which allows for a more engaging cat-and-mouse game to emerge. However, when the enemies have no significant weakness in their design, you start to realize the unintended weaknesses they have such as their poor path finding or unreliable detection systems. I would definitely avoid this game if you prioritize a solid game play experience over all else. 

The other elements of the game are significantly more engaging though, and I think are better left faced as they come up so I will not go into further depth than that. Overall, the narrative and atmosphere more than make up for the relatively poor game play so I recommend this game with that moderately large caveat.

144157241.review:
Oh goodness, where to begin?

I'll start with my biggest gripe with this game, which is the overall story. It's... disjointed at best, indecipherable at worst. Simon, the main character, is very interesting at the beginning, and the game does a good job to make me care about him. But then very quickly, it makes me NOT care about him, and makes me feel very disconnected from the character at the beginning {spoiler footnote 1}.

The character motivations also feel very weak, and when they're not, they're all over the place. The best example of this is Catherine. {spoiler footnote 2} She just feels like she exists to give Simon someone to bounce off of and dump halfhearted philosophy onto.

The villain of the game {spoiler footnote 3} is also basically a non-threat the entire time. Sure, it makes "scary" monsters that chase you around, but nothing more. The creatures aren't even that scary, either. Most of the gameplay for dealing with any of them is "don't get too close" and "just hide in a corner." I streamed this game for my fiance, and he had the liberty of seeing me quite literally just stand in a corner for five minutes while waiting for a monster in the same room to eventually leave me alone. I wasn't hiding, either -- just standing about six-ish feet away from the monster, and staring into a corner in a wide open room. It eventually just got bored and left, I guess. Really killed the action of trying to escape it, honestly.

I could go on, but I think I've made my point. Overall, I found SOMA to be lacking in story, writing, character development, and gameplay. I've certainly played worse, but I think $30 for this is a bit ridiculous. 3/10.

Here be spoiler footnotes

1. [spoiler] When it's revealed that the original Simon died, and that this is the brainscan taken of him shoved into a robot, I felt like nothing really mattered anymore anyway. If [i]this[/i] Simon died, what's to stop Catherine from just making a new Simon? She already does it TWICE in the game anyway. [/spoiler]

2. [spoiler] Catherine wants to launch the ARK into space to save humanity's legacy. Or... to help humanity live on, as the ARK can apparently only get energy from solar panels (to say nothing of the giant geothermal power plant nearby that can quote "generate enough power until the next Apocalypse".) Or... or in hopes the ARK is found by aliens and they do... sooooomething with the brainscans? That last one would be interesting, if it was even mentioned at all in the game. It feels as though the reason the ARK needs to be launched into space is constantly changing. A data buffer of Catherine's at one point has her say something about the ARK being a "terrarium that will die in a few decades" if it's left on Earth, but a "new era for mankind" if it's launched into space. This is never expounded upon. [/spoiler]

[spoiler] Honestly, Catherine is just a really poorly written character in my opinion. It feels like she just exists to give the player a goal -- to get the ARK into space, and that's it. Honestly, she could have been a lot of fun if they really worked with the whole "she is manipulating Simon into launching the ARK into space no matter what, even though she knows there's a chance they won't be the copies to make it onto it" angle. But no, Simon is made out to be the bad guy in the end for yelling at her. You know, after she [i] didn't explain how the brainscans work.[/i] [/spoiler]

3. [spoiler] The WAU. Honestly, I felt like it could have been a better villain, especially if they had worked with the whole "it's just a machine -- it's just a logical cancer" angle more. It could have been, like, a corrupted HAL -- smart and cunning -- but instead it was basically a corrupted 3D monster printer. It had no mind of its own, and just existed to have Scary Monsters all over the place. Plus, once it IS revealed, it chases you for maybe ten minutes (that's including hiding time!) and then is never ever mentioned again. Supposedly, Simon kills it, but this is never reflected in the game.[/spoiler]

Overrated walking simulator. None of the exploration of Amnesia. No reward for exploring. No Tinderboxes, and no resources. 

Monster is annoying and simply blocks your path to progress. Can't skip dialogue. When you are reading the memory of something, the monster is still running around, but you're "stunned" as you read memory. The water parts are horrible and drawn out. 143705244.review:
First if all, I’d like to point out that the human consciousness and anything related to it is one of my deep interests, Especially stories and random theories, And this game is a fictional (of course) horror game, What better setting to start working with? The subject is something you can get extremely philosophical with, It’s just generally thought provoking and I am into anything thought provoking!

Since I started with what the story is about, I will talk more about it next, It’s one of the best experiences I’ve had with any video game story, It uses all the elements needed and then some to make you crave more of it… It’s just generally well written and you can not find anything wrong with it (except one weird little, And I mean extremely little hiccup which you wouldn’t even notice if you’re not that much of a realist), It’s paced well and you don’t get bored and also it has times when stuff you discover just click and make the plot make more sense, the game knows how to progressively give you information and paint a bigger picture. The game has a lot of the story written down for you to discover and read, Albeit not as much of a core mechanic since the game is linear in terms of gameplay and not much of a “explore and find” type, It’s more of a addition to what you experience throughout the game, More of those satisfying clicks.

The gameplay, as I mentioned earlier it’s linear, Also it’s a walking simulator, You’re not gonna start 360 no scoping monsters out of nowhere since there are no weapons here, It’s a stealth oriented horror game that encourages you to run and hide, peek around corners and all in all take it slow and enjoy the “scenery”. It’s no cheap horror game either, it doesn’t rely on cheap jump scares to make you punch the screen, Instead it gives you a heart attack. It actually scares you on a instinctive level like how you would react if you were actually in that scenario, I was TERRIFIED while playing this game, Also quick thing to point out, After playing Dead space (2008) I realized how much I hated horror, SOMA was especially hard to play for me since the fear was so real, I took a 2-3 day off after playing the first like 1/8 of the game, I am not exaggerating.

Remember the “scenery” I mentioned earlier? You’ll either love it, or love it in a hateful manner since it’s so scary, It’s so well designed and well executed that I have no way to describe it other than perfect, You WILL inch through it and you WILL take it all in. No way for you to not look at anything, Unless you have balls of titanium or something. The atmosphere is so good that you will constantly feel like you’re being watched, Again that’s not really a good thing in real life but for a game to manage that is not that easy, The sound design is nothing short of perfect either.

Listen, there’s a reason this game is “Overwhelmingly Positive” in steam reviews, These don’t just appear out of thin air, There’s a whole game to back those up so just do yourself a favor and play it. I would give this a 10/10.

143667596.review: My favorite title from Frictional so far. The story, the mystery, the horror, the theories it spurred in my mind, the emotional journey it took me on, I love this game. This is not jumpscares but existential dread and disturbing horror at its finest, just try it.

I usually don't like to play horror games, but this one was mind-blowing. I loved the ambiance in those hostile stations, and also the fact that you have to think about a way to evade every enemy you encounter and continue the story. Also, I really appreciate that the game continues without loading screens or long cutscenes while playing. When autosaving, a small icon appears on the bottom right side of the screen. You are kept in Simon Jarrett's POV the whole time and that makes it even more immersive.

This game had such a sad ending that left me questioning about what is life? What is consciousness? What does it mean to be human? How much the idea of myself depends on where I am? [spoiler]- interesting quote from Simon -[/spoiler]. This was a great story with stressing enemy encounters - specially for people like me who don't play this type of games -, awesome post-apocalyptic landscapes and a despairing/hopeful ending. Yes, both at the same time.

[spoiler]I loved Sarang's quotes, even though they are just part of his 'Continuity' theory. But those quotes reminded me a lot to Theseus' paradox.

"You are not your body, you are the emergent entity, that entity just happens to occupy two places at once for a while. If you took away your body, you would simply be the only one you can be, the [i]you[/i] inside the ARK. Let your body die, and continue on in the digital paradise among the stars".[/spoiler]

10/10

143455639.review: I beat the game a few years back and I was blown away by the storytelling. Horror games, in my opinion, don't usually have a good story (if they even have one at all). Soma is an absolute gem and brilliantly written. After doing some research on the game, it seems that a lot of players (myself included) get hung up on the whole "transfer" thing. There is no transfer. It's impossible to transfer your consciousness because consciousness relies on the very thing that gives rise to it (in our case, a biological brain). Our consciousness cannot exist separately from the brain. That's like saying that a fire can exist without the fuel that sustains it. So you see, Simon's mind was never transferred in the first place, but merely copied. Essentially, there are four different Simons, one dead and three existing at the same time (if you chose to spare the Simon at Omicron). They only think they're the continuation of the original because from the perspective of the new copy, they did carry over, while from the perspective of the old copy, they're still "stuck" in their original body. So the last three think they're the original Simon, but in truth, all four Simons are four different people. Back at site Theta, you missed an audio log in Sarang's room that explains this concept. You can have multiple copies of the same being existing at once, but the copies eventually become different people because of "divergence", meaning that their minds change due to their unique experiences as time goes on (in Neuroscience, that's called neuroplasticity and it's the reason why identical twins have unique personalities despite having identical DNA). Essentially though, you got it at the very end. It's confusing in a way because the multiple copies of Simon kept thinking that they were going to get transferred when that was never a possibility to begin with. I'm glad you gave Soma a chance Hollow. It's a fucking fantastic game and one hell of a ride. It was enjoyable seeing you go through those "ah-ha!" moments. For me, it was like playing it all over again.

143248810.review:
[h1][b] René Descartes:
The Mind-Body Distinction [/b][/h1]

One of the deepest and most lasting legacies of Descartes’ philosophy is his thesis that mind and body are really distinct—a thesis now called “mind-body dualism.” He reaches this conclusion by arguing that the nature of the mind is completely different from that of the body, and therefore it is possible for one to exist without the other. This argument gives rise to the famous problem of mind-body causal interaction still debated today: how can the mind cause some of our bodily limbs to move (for example, raising one’s hand to ask a question), and how can the body’s sense organs cause sensations in the mind when their natures are completely different?

This game was worth it.

Throughout the game, you are presented with a lot of moral choices. While these might not impact the ending itself, but they definitely do have a reason to be there. I give this game a 7/10 and definitely recommend everyone to pick it up on a sale if you want a good experience.

This is so far only horror game I finished, and I must say it was totally worth it.

Even after 8 years of release, SOMA is an absolute gem of a horror game. The atmosphere it creates is so immersive, you'll feel like you're right there in the eerie depths of PATHOS-II. The visuals and sounds are excellent, drawing you into a terryfing undersea facility filled with tension and mystery.

What sets SOMA apart is its thought-provoking narrative. It looks into the philosophical questions about consciousness, identity, and the human condition. The story will stay with you long after you finish the game, making you ponder the mysteries of existence.

The gameplay is solid, with some well-crafted puzzles that go with the story. The choices you make carry weight, adding emotional depth to your journey.

In short, if you're looking for a horror game that goes beyond some adrenaline rush in form of some jumpscares, SOMA is a must-play. It's a gripping, atmospheric experience that'll leave you contemplating life's biggest questions.

Rating:⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐ (5 out of 5 tentacled monstrosities) 💀

143001242.review:
SOMA remains an absolute gem and easily ranks among my all-time favorite games. From the moment you step into its world, you're enveloped in an immersive atmosphere that captivates your senses. The attention to detail is remarkable; every nook and cranny feels lived in, and the layouts are carefully crafted, avoiding any sense that they were merely designed to accommodate gameplay or puzzles.

The true brilliance of SOMA lies in its thought-provoking themes. Drawing on the complexities of transhumanism and delving into the very essence of what defines us as individuals, the game poses profound philosophical questions about what it means to be human. No other game has left such a profound impact on me, resonating with existential ponderings that continue to linger long after the credits roll.

As I eagerly await Frictional's next offering, I can't help but wish for more attention to be given to SOMA. While Amnesia receives content updates, it's disheartening to see SOMA seemingly overlooked. Nevertheless, I hold onto hope, knowing that Frictional's talent for crafting immersive experiences will likely lead to something extraordinary.

In conclusion, SOMA is an unforgettable journey into the depths of our humanity, and it stands as a testament to the power of gaming as an art form. I eagerly anticipate what the future holds for Frictional, with the belief that they will continue to astound us with their visionary storytelling and exceptional world-building.

But underwater can be much scarier, because it is the same space, only around you are not twinkling stars, lighting the way. No, there is only cold and darkness around, literally within a meter radius the light of a flashlight does not penetrate through the water column. But it lures the eyes. It lures those monsters that can see in the dark, whose silhouettes glide beside you, inspecting and studying you until they finally get hungry....

Trust me, it's not just a horror game, it's more than that. Soma is unique in its kind and you will hardly meet a game that can be similar to it. The main feature, from which the developers tried to squeeze out the maximum is described above - the seabed, where you have to wander in complete solitude to go from one red fire to another, hoping that you will not be swallowed by the darkness, that what lives there, will not wake up, will not hear you. Running from one complex to another, you will hope that this will be the last one, because even with what lives in the stations, it is much more comfortable than under the open sea sky.

Even if you don't like water, don't like horrors - try it, this game will give you new emotions and will diversify some evenings, and maybe even make you think, because the plot there can please you.

142831894.review:
This game is incredible to say the least. This is the highest quality horror experience I've ever had.

It is a beautifully written horror game that doesn't overly rely on old cliches and chase sequences. SOMA is a story-driven horror of the experience game. Immersing yourself into the story is not hard, but the game does not hold your hand either. The writing for this game is among the best I've ever witnessed. The voice actors also put up a great performance with it. The characters are believable. I feel immensely strong emotions about them.

SOMA' job isn't to make you terrified the whole time you play the game, nor does it provide strong gameplay. SOMA does have you running and hiding from monsters, solving puzzles, and uncovering mysteries. SOMA is not a game intended for all audiences. The gameplay compared to other horror games, especially actions horror games, might leave certain players bored. If you are someone who craves strong stories, psychological horror, moral dilemmas, and emotional experiences, this game is made for you.

The monster A.I. does it's job for the most part. It's nothing to write home about. I'd like to have seen some improvements, but honestly, monsters aren't the focus of this game. SOMA plays to other strengths, and it's better off for it in the long run as a game. That doesn't mean the monster A.I. couldn't be a little better to keep immersion up, but it doesn't detract much from the experience. SOMA also ditches resource management which heavily plays to it's strength in my opinion.

This game is an experience I will never forget and has forever changed my perspective on horror games. SOMA is a refined experience. The game is a 10/10 all the way through for me. One of those games that I'm sure I will wish I can wipe my mind and experience it all for the first time again.

Soma is one of those pleasant surprises that comes along every now and again.
A Story that has a theme and diligently and thoroughly explores it.
From the starting position of a man who has his brain scanned in the year 2015, to a fish out of water in the year 2104 we explore what it means to be human, the ethical concerns of artificial intelligence, metaphysical ideas of souls and how that ties to consciousness.

Gameplay is the usual Frictional Games fair, it's alright to begin with and drags a bit by the end. When you can see a map of an area and tell from that, and that alone, what's about to happen next. That's not good.
If story and character can get you through 9 hours of Mediocre gameplay then I'd say this is worth a buy, especially if you can get it on sale.

The 'scary' factor was just right, keeping me on edge without blocking my progress.

142269126.review:
In SOMA, the player assumes the role of Simon Jarrett, a man who finds himself in an underwater research facility called PATHOS-II. Simon, dealing with a tragic accident in his own life, wakes up in this mysterious facility to discover that the world around him has drastically changed.

As Simon explores the depths of PATHOS-II, he encounters grotesque humanoid machines and must evade them to survive. However, the true horror lies in the philosophical questions raised by the narrative. Simon discovers that the facility's experiments in transhumanism have resulted in the creation of digital copies of human consciousness. These copies, known as "simulations," harbor the memories and identities of the original humans but are trapped in a nightmarish existence.

Driven by a desire to understand his own circumstances and find a way out, Simon navigates the dilapidated corridors of PATHOS-II and encounters other survivors who are also grappling with their own existential crises. The game delves into profound themes of identity, consciousness, and what it truly means to be human.

Throughout the journey, players are forced to confront unsettling philosophical dilemmas as they make choices that challenge the boundaries of morality. The story reaches its climax as Simon confronts the unsettling truth of his own existence and must make a choice that could have far-reaching consequences for himself and the digital consciousness trapped within PATHOS-II.

SOMA's plot leaves players questioning their own perception of reality and the nature of humanity, presenting a haunting narrative that lingers in the mind long after the game is finished.

Prepare to be immersed in a bone-chilling odyssey that explores the darkest corners of horror, philosophy, and the enigmatic nature of humanity. Frictional Games' SOMA unleashes a terrifying experience that will haunt your thoughts long after the game has ended.

From the moment you step into SOMA's grim world, you'll be entranced by its eerie and macabre visuals. While the graphics could have been more refined, they effectively transport you into a realm teeming with desolate environments, where abandoned structures loom ominously, and bioluminescent sea creatures lurk in the depths. And then there are the horrifying humanoid machines, twisted creations that will send shivers down your spine with their grotesque presence.

But it's the plot of SOMA that truly sets it apart, plunging you into a maelstrom of existential dread. Transhumanism, consciousness, and the very essence of identity intertwine, weaving a narrative that relentlessly forces you to question the very fabric of your being. Prepare to confront the haunting realization of what it means to be human when confronted with a world where consciousness can be digitized and copied. The voice acting and writing are masterfully executed, breathing life into characters and their moral dilemmas, leaving you emotionally entangled in their harrowing struggles.

While SOMA's gameplay mechanics may not redefine the genre, they serve as a conduit to amplify your vulnerability and enhance the visceral horror experience. As you explore the shadowy depths, solving diabolical puzzles and desperately hiding from grotesque monstrosities, you'll be consumed by a palpable sense of terror. Brace yourself for a journey where cheap jump scares take a backseat, and psychological torment lurks around every corner, ingeniously crafted through the game's spine-chilling atmosphere and deeply unsettling narrative.

SOMA's audio design warrants special recognition, as it plunges you further into the abyss of terror. The distant moans of the forsaken station, the bone-chilling echoes of indescribable creatures, and the sporadic transmissions from desperate survivors converge to create a haunting symphony of fear. The sparing use of music heightens the tension at pivotal story moments, leaving your nerves taut and your heart racing.

However, it's essential to acknowledge a few minor flaws in SOMA's harrowing journey. Pacing issues occasionally surface, with stretches of the game feeling sluggish between crucial story developments. Furthermore, the enemy AI can become somewhat predictable in repeated encounters, diminishing the fear factor to some extent.

SOMA emerges as a chilling tour de force, seamlessly blending heart-stopping horror, profound philosophical exploration, and the raw essence of what it truly means to be human. Despite minor pacing hiccups and occasional AI predictability, Frictional Games has crafted a game that will leave you trembling and questioning your own existence. Brace yourself for a nightmare-inducing experience that transcends the boundaries of traditional horror games. SOMA will seep into your very soul, forever etching its terrifying tale in your darkest memories. Enter this abyss of horror and philosophy at your own risk – but be prepared to confront the chilling truth that awaits within

142239405.review: I don't even know what to say. This game is beyond amazing. But I will say it is incredibly existential so if you're looking to have a happy fun time you should actually be avoiding this game. I have never seen an ending to any sort of media leaving me with so many different emotions. I don't know if I should feel happy sad, angry, pity, or relief. There were so many moments where you had to make really tough decisions regarding the other "humans" around you and just ask yourself questions such as: "Should I keep them alive?" "Would it be better if they knew the truth?" "Would death really be worse than a fate like this?". This game raises so many questions about mortality that really just keep me up at night. There's this one part in the game where you find a card containing the consciousness of one of the dead crew members and you need information out of him. So the way you'd communicate with him would be to simulate the consciousness in a certain digital environment and try your hardest to convince him into giving you the information you need. If he got suspicious you'd have to shut the simulation down and start over again but since it is HIS CONSCIOUSNESS that you are shutting down and rebooting there's a chance you're just killing him and bringing him back mercilessly. There are tons of moments just like that along with the ending that just makes this game so unbelievably tragic. And I love it.

142111884.review:
[h1]SOMA is an superb story-focused psychological horror that has the most interesting story of any game. Thought-provoking and intense, it's a very solid experience. Best experienced with very little info.[/h1]
[h2]Note: I am not someone who gets easily scared by horror games, nor who has a lot of experience with various horror games. I've played Amnesia: TDD, and that's about it.[/h2]

[hr][/hr]

[h2]Likes:[/h2]
[list]
	[*]Story is terrifying and raises a lot of moral and ethical thought-provoking questions. Discussing these afterwards with friends adds to the fun
	[*]Instead of separate levels separated by physical barriers, it takes the more Half-Life esque approach of areas which serve as loading zone triggers which load the next map. Besides some texture loading issues with these areas, it feels really good and seamless
	[*]Has [spoiler]questionnaires[/spoiler] throughout the game that really add to the experience in a minimal and unobtrusive way
	[*]Puzzles are alright, but they could be more complex. I think it was for the best for them to have simpler puzzles to allow access to less experienced puzzlers though. Puzzles are generally satisfying and intriguing though
	[*]Flashlight is totally useless, but it helps add to the horror
	[*]People having [spoiler]blackboxes[/spoiler] is an awesome mechanic and the way that interacts with the player and monsters is nothing short of incredible
	[*]In general, the way the world and mechanics combine is some of the best work I've seen in a game. It's so seamless and so logical you'd think this actually happened
	[*]The moral dilemmas the game asks you to try and solve are heartbreaking
	[*]Audio/text logs are super cool and it's really fun to connect the dots on what happened to various people and places. Love the lore; I found myself actively looking for more terminals to find out more things
	[*]Jumpscares feel earned, and they're super limited in number
	[*]Exploration is really top-tier. One of the best parts of the game
	[*]Ending is absolutely brutal. Just. Brutal.
[/list]

[h2]Dislikes:[/h2]
[list]
	[*]Slow to get to the more physical horror like monsters; took around 2 hours
	[*]I wish there were resources to manage like in Amnesia
	[*]Can miss very important pieces of dialogue if you interact with something else
	[*]A lot of quiet areas have this really thought provoking dialogue between you and another character, but it also happens while you're doing puzzles or asked to explore the environment. I'm the type of person who can't really do this multi-tasking, but that's just me
	[*]Opening doors, lockers, and other items feels awful compared to Amnesia. I have to yank my mouse across the screen.
	[*]It is hard to understand the monsters; the game doesn't want you to look at them, so it's really hard to understand their weakenesses or abilities sometimes through their visual design. This happened with Robot Head for me
	[*]The health system is weird. The game should just kill you if you mess up. Being injured just sucks. It also hurts the physical horror aspect
	[*]Missed some moments in the game like [spoiler]looking at yourself in the mirror[/spoiler] due to unclear design
	[*]No choices on what to say during dialogue; I found myself disagreeing with some of the things that Simon would say. Would help me immerse myself more in the role. On the other hand, Simon is really his own character here, and it's important to the story. So I don't really know.
	[*]I agree with Joseph Anderson in his review (on YouTube) where he thinks the ending gives too much to the player. I agree, and I really like his alternate ending, which has some really cool story ideas that could blossom into something greater.
[/list]

Died only twice in the game.
Best experienced in two hour intervals.

I've only played a very limited list of horror games, so I'm not the best on scare factor, but I can say I very much enjoyed my time with SOMA. It's worth it if only for the story. Playing it in the game's Safe mode is honestly not a bad idea.

142086099.review:
[h1]A unique experience in the deepest human sense[/h1]

This game is extraordinary. I'd already played it when I was younger and the ending seemed completely crazy, creating hundreds of knots in my brain over existential questions. 

What makes us human? What makes us humankind? To live artificially or to die? Illusion or truth? 

SOMA is a truly brilliant and intense experience, with each monster encountered having its own pattern that the player must interpret and understand. The atmosphere is particularly successful, and the "people" you meet are really endearing. The game's story is fascinating and its gameplay effective: running and hiding. The game raises questions and reasoning by drawing on several different disciplines: philosophy, science, idealism...

I hope you'll enjoy the experience as much or more than I did. 

[b]18/20[/b]

141668591.review:
- Gameplay is satisfying at first, but overstays it's welcome and gets stale, bland and repetitive throughout the course of the game.

- The level design is probably the worst aspect of the game. Nothing interesting happens, and the objectives similar to gameplay, are very repetitive. The puzzles are boring and designed very artificially.

- I didn't find anything remotely horror in the game. The setting, initially was interesting and somewhat creepy, but in the flow of the game, it loses all its creepiness. There are monsters, who are goofy dudes roaming in front of you which you just have to hide from. They appear only for like 10% of the game so you don't have to keep thinking of them.  If they catch you, you instantly respawn at the same place you were caught as if you're playing a CoD deathmatch. They are just funny to look at, not scary from any angle. There are only two difficulties, one where monster can attack you, and one where it can't. So there's no challenge aswell.

 - Voice acting and sound design are below average. So, as described above the monsters, you go below the stairs in one sequence, do a thing and escape the monster, when you go back above the stairs, the protagonist has something great to say, "This better have worked, I am not going down there again. "
Totally shivers you to the core, doesn't it? The game itself doesn't take it seriously and there are constant corny lines which just break the immersion, whatever of that is left. 

- The graphics and engine are one of the best aspect of the game.

- There are two elements, the story and the lore, the story dealing with what we see and related to our character and the lore related to the world and the background.
 
--The lore is straight up awful, and there's nothing great or mindblowing to learn about the background of the world.
-- The story, revolving the protagonist and what we see, also just has a start and an end, there is nothing related to the story during the gameplay that progresses, no twists, change in conflicts or anything.
You can describe the story in a small paragraph and that would be it.

It was really a tough job to end the game, but it somewhat redeemed because the ending was above average, related to all the stuff that happened before. But I would never recommend wasting 10+ hours on it, there is much better stuff out there. 
If you are remotely interested in the concept, you are better off just reading about it somewhere, or watching a summary on youtube.

141658076.review:
It's a great game and an awesome story. 10/10 story I would say.

I do have to subtract 2 points because:

(1) There were some puzzles where I moved to every corner, hovered over everything and clicked at everything I could - I had no idea what to do. So I had to look it up (shoutout to AdamSpencer87 on YouTube) and when I saw the solutions I always thought 'nah dude.. that's ridiculous.. how was I supposed to know that I have to do that?!?!'.

(2) There were a few moments where I was running around not knowing what I am actually supposed to do and then doing stuff without knowing the in-game-character actually able to know whether that makes any sense.. felt a bit underwhelming at these times.


2 notes:

(1) The main question I had when playing this game was 'Why am I stucking my arm into the blue holes? And what is happening then?'. This seemed to be an important part of the gameplay but actually did not do anything notable and I still have not the slightest idea why I am actually doing that. I dislike it and I will google it after writing this review.

(2) Why did Simon have to be such a stupid asshole right after the launch.. I really liked the character until that point and could identify with him but that made me feel so angry and disconnected to him. grrrr...


In conclusion: All in all I give it a strong 8/10. Definitely can recommend it when it's on sale.

141278033.review: I have played two games from Frictional Games. First Amnesia and Soma. And the prize goes, definitely, to Soma. Compared to Amnesia, Frictional Games clearly invested in the story here, and not in "die of fear, sitting behind a box, meat bag." But, at the same time, the game is quite remained a horror. Darkness, silence, creaks, a deserted Earth, and there is nothing in the future, but something incomprehensible is already screaming behind. Meat bags, yes. Soma, by the way, also about humanity. Or rather, their extinction. And the last throwing in agony. And here, of course, there is not enough branching for several endings. There is not enough variation of unity with the WAU, there is not enough variation of working out a new evolution on the planet, and the variation that the Ark was infected. And in vain they cut out the dialogues from the alpha-version. But it doesn't get any worse, of course. It just could have been better. And everything would be perfectly superimposed on philosophizing on the topic "What am I?", and what is "Being a real person", and other transhumanism, on which the game is built. 9 gel jars out of 10.

Hablando de la historia, este es uno de los puntos mas fuertes del juego. Algo que realmente te hará reflexionar y parar por un momento. No solo se trata de sentir miedo, se trata de entender quien eres en el fondo. Todo esto junto a un mundo fascinante y que no terminas nunca de aprender de el hacen de este juego una de las mejores experiencias de terror que he probado en mucho tiempo. La música también hace del juego mas inmerso y las emociones se pueden compartir al momento de estar en diversas situaciones. Sus personajes, irónicamente, de verdad se sienten humanos y sus decisiones tienen sentido con el mundo que los rodea. Una experiencia que merece la pena sin duda.  10/10 ign

141178776.review:
I generally don't play horror games, but Soma combines many aspects into a brilliant slow burn of terror and dread into its story that I found very interesting. The atmosphere of the game, sounds, subtle details, all add to the tension as you progress through an underwater facility where something catastrophic has occurred. Soma has an incredibly good story and uses the interactivity to give weight and thought to the actions your character does.

Unfortunately, Soma still fails to make any enemy encounter has any of that weight or terror, because you can just respawn. The first time an any catches you, you just wake up right where you were, with some visual artifacts, and can continue about your business; the next time you simply reload to the last checkpoint. This means that only the first encounter is actually meaningful and hide and seek sections just become tedious and annoying instead of frightening. This game actually has a safe mode (as oppose to normal difficulty) which removes the ability to die, and It begs the question that if you just meet the game where it is and "act" like they will kill you if they get you, would that actually be a more terrifying experience? 

Imagine you enter a room, a monster starts chasing you and you desperately try to get away to a safe room. If you get caught you just respawn, all the tension is gone, while when you get to the room you hear banging on the door as it looks and loud shrieks from the other side. On safe mode, the initial tension of the chase is always preserved (provided you don't just walk up to the monster because you know it wont kill you), where as on normal mode you get caught, respawn and just try again with no consequences.

Given that, I would argue that if you don't abuse it, playing on safe mode might actually be more terrifying since dying typically ruins these situations.

Regardless, Soma is a great game and I would highly recommend, even if you don't typically enjoy horror games, but the game play can really detract from an exceptional story.

The enjoyment of this game comes a lot from it's narrative and if you're a person that doesn't really enjoy games that make you ask yourself thought provoking questions whilst occasionally running away from the big bad monsters this game likely isn't for you. If you are a person however that really enjoys the narrative of games or just someone who really likes horror games I highly recommend this game.

The visuals despite being 7 years old are surprisingly good. 

The atmosphere of the game and music are really good despite music being very sparse and a lot of the game will leave you in silence as you hear your footsteps and maybe someone/something else's as well.

The Difficulty is well fairly easy I only ever died once during the entire game and that was to see what would happen if you did die.

The Story is where this game shines, if you're someone who likes to engage with the story you're going to love it as it really tries to ask questions, makes you question your own morality, and I also personally had a really fun time trying to figure out the mystery of the game and what happened.

TLDR: Really good story despite it being fairly easy and gameplay also fun

140598796.review:
From the moment you enter the eerie, underwater complex of PATHOS-II, the game impresses with its meticulous world-building and atmospheric design. The environments are both beautiful and haunting, filled with abandoned structures, bioluminescent sea creatures, and horrifying humanoid machines.

The plot of SOMA is perhaps its most striking aspect. Involving themes such as transhumanism, consciousness, and the nature of identity, the story remains thought-provoking long after the game is finished. The narrative pulls no punches, exploring what it truly means to be human in a world where consciousness can be digitized and copied. The voice acting and writing are excellent, adding depth to the characters and their dilemmas.

While SOMA's gameplay mechanics aren't groundbreaking - mostly involving exploration, solving puzzles, and hiding from monsters - they serve their purpose well, creating a sense of vulnerability that enhances the overall horror. However, it is important to note that the game doesn't rely on cheap jump scares; instead, it builds psychological dread through its atmosphere and story.

SOMA's audio design deserves special mention. The distant groans of the station, the echoes of unseen creatures, and the sporadic communications from other survivors combine to create an immersive, foreboding soundscape. The music is sparse, but effectively used, punctuating key story moments and ramping up the tension when necessary.

The game does have a few shortcomings, primarily in its pacing. Some sections can feel slow, with lengthy stretches between story developments. The enemy AI can sometimes be a bit predictable, which can detract from the horror in repeated encounters.

In conclusion, SOMA is much more than a traditional survival horror game. It's a deep dive into unsettling philosophical concepts, presented within a richly detailed and atmospheric world. Despite minor pacing issues and occasionally lackluster AI, it stands out as an exemplar of narrative-focused games. This isn't a game you'll easily forget - and it's likely one you'll find yourself thinking about long after you've put it down

140594288.review: This is easily one of the games of all time

140588569.review:
When you’re first thrust into the world of Soma, alone and in an unfamiliar research facility many hundreds of feet below the surface, you’re just as confused as the titular protagonist Simon is. With the help of a quickly acquired companion by the name of Catherine, who guides you through your journey by voice alone, you begin to discover the nature of the world around you and learn of a potential last hope for humanity after a catastrophic event.

During this voyage you traverse numerous research stations and underwater locations, all eerily empty except for the few machines that remain. It’s this somber setting that serves as the backdrop to the real bread and butter of the game, Simon’s conversations with Catherine, both about what the world’s become and more philosophical topics like, “what is consciousness?”, “what does it mean to be you?”, and “when do we cease to exist, really?”. All seamlessly strung together in a way that feels inexplicably natural despite the circumstances in which you’re asking them.

In this interweaving of setting and narrative, Soma does something really special. While both can be admired independently for their contemplative qualities and visuals, there is more to it than just that. The various desolate and rundown locations serve as a perfect fuel for the narrative, adding a complementary dash of loneliness, sorrow, and awe. Of course it helps that the game is legitimately beautiful too, and even allows you to toggle a safe mode option, letting you play the game without fear of dying to potential threats. It’s a nice setting for when you want a cerebral experience as opposed to a more visceral one.

My only lament is that it ended at all, but I am satisfied with its length and message. The longer I played the more enthralled I became in the overarching story of failure, redemption, and hope. All that said, don’t think Soma is a non-stop montage of conversation. The game knows when to cease the chatter and let you take in the world, but you know they've succeeded in hooking your interest when you’re excited for the next time Simon or Catherine open their mouths.

140355506.review:
This is a story-driven game, primarily. The story has great potential but is [i]ruined[/i] by the game spoon-feeding you all of the answers, repeatedly.

I'm not going to spoil much. I'll just say this: there is a Thing that happens, three times throughout the game.
The first time the Thing happens, your protagonist is not aware of what is going on, so he's rightfully confused. But he later meets someone who explains -- in plain English, that a child could understand -- what happened to him. And he does seem to get it.
Then the Thing happens a second time. And suddenly, he's surprised and confused again, he's even [i]angry[/i] at his companion for "not explaining" it to him, even though she literally did.
Then the third time. This one is treated as a sort of grand reveal by the game, as if it's finally giving you an answer, as if this is a key event of the story, a culmination... but it's [i]the exact same Thing![/i] And your protagonist STILL doesn't get what's happening!

By the ending, I was just mad. Not only was the character dumb, but the game seemingly thought that I, the player, am just as dumb as him, overexplaining things to that extent and still expecting me to be surprised at the exact same event happening once again... Disappointing. It could have been so much better.

140292285.review:
To make it short: PLAY IT!

While it doesn't really look like it upfront, it has a very high depth for thoughts to come by, in a very differentiated way, meaning you will get some hints to the story or anything related to it subtle, but sometimes also frighteningly direct.

Some passages of the game allow to chill a bit and let the new informations you gather over time sink in, read and eat your food while you're at it. And some passages are so intense, that at some point you will scream and you will tell yourself "what the fuck" in shorter periods of time.

Its excellent, a masterpiece in its story and the overall story telling. The locations are stunning in their own ways and it never felt disconnected, or like you would work off passages. I was wondering where this is going up until the very end and I liked the thought process you undergo yourself way more than the ending itself. It was no where near bad, though. 

Sure, this game seems to miss some gameplay elements you could think about in a scenario like this, you might know "similar" releases that came after SOMA, like Prey, where you got weapons free to use and other RPG-lite elements. I was sceptical, but I can assure you, this is no downer and helps immersing way better, as a normal guy (that the protagonist is) you mostly only do stuff that normal people can do without any big instruction or expert level knowledge.

Because of this, I like to believe SOMA kind of developed a good basis for such future games to add gameplay elements on (or it just advanced them), telling stories with a thick and horrific atmosphere in a very own pacing and a delightful kind of way.

Honestly, first time I played SOMA it didn't catch me after like one hour, so 9 years later I gave it another try and- OH BOI has my view on this changed.

SOMA is a gem, and sadly was a hidden gem for me for a long time. I robbed myself a first playthrough way longer than I should and I really want to encourage you to start your first playthrough just NOW, ASAP at least, because you shouldn't do the same mistake I did.

140291568.review:
[h1]SOMA[/h1]
This game will make you experience an existential crisis countless times. (Definitely worth it)
[b]Storyline[/b]
Plot and idea of this game are just brilliant. You will play as a Simon Jarrett - a guy from Toronto, born in 1988. Before his death, he did a scan of his brain. And after approximately 100 years [i]he?[/i] wakes up in an underwater research facility known as PATHOS-II. And so, here we go...
[b]Ambience[/b]
Atmosphere in this game amazing. Each crack or strange sound will make you fear, but what do you fear more: monsters, environment or [i]yourself[/i]? Also you should check out what surrounds you, you're really under hundreds of meters of water, all alone with your fears...
[b]Gameplay[/b]
The gameplay is not the strongest point of this game. The whole thing is in the ambience and storyline, but i can't not mention 3 sections in a row with the same enemies. Sometimes you won't understand how to distract them, but that's ok. And don't forget to read all the information given to you, it's really important.
[b]Conclusion[/b]
SOMA is that kind of game that you must play. While playing, you'll think a lot about your life, your past and your future. And about [i]you[/i]... I'd definitely recommend it. [But I bought it while it was on a sale]

[b]7 Self Awareness thoughts out of 10[/b]

140284436.review:
SOMA is not a game that relies on jump scares or gore, but rather on creating a tense and immersive atmosphere. The game uses a physical interaction system that lets you manipulate objects in the environment, which adds to the realism and immersion. The game also has a compelling sci-fi story that raises philosophical questions about consciousness, identity, and morality. The game challenges you to make difficult choices that have consequences for yourself and others.

SOMA is a game that will make you think and feel, as well as scare you. It's is not an overly long game either, not over staying its welcome.

140248412.review:
I really wish I could recommend this game. I want to be clear- I played it all the way through and I enjoyed it. Everything all the other reviewers are saying is absolutely true and what I experienced will definitely stay with me.

But I almost abandoned the game more than once because the view bob- something I've never minded in any other game, and never disabled even in those titles that allow you to do so -is so extreme, so exaggerated, that I couldn't play for long without succumbing to headaches and nausea.

You can't turn it off, and worse, the view bob is amplified to extremes whenever you are injured. I almost put down the game during an extended sequence where I had used the only source of healing in the area and was still hurt because I could not play without making myself ill.

Again, I've never in my life had this happen with any other game. Usually I like view bob! Or at least I don't notice it. So when I tell you it's out of control in this game, I'm really not kidding.

The only reason I was able to complete the game was because some helpful people on the internet discovered you can disable it by editing the game files, a thing I should not have to do to be able to play a game.

You can install a mod to turn off view bob. But you can't do it in the middle of a playthrough or you'll be forced to start over. So if you're midway through the story and desperate for relief, editing the files is your only option.

Even when you do, you will quickly discover that the game has no other method by which to indicate to you that you are injured, except for a subtle chromatic aberration effect. Oh well. Good luck!

The game goes too hard with some of its other effects, sometimes in ways that make no sense. Near the end of the game you find yourself in a diving suit in very deep water, and to illustrate the pressure, the game... turns on extremely aggressive depth of field, rendering you profoundly nearsighted? Why? It makes the entire sequence much more irritating (and, again, headache-inducing) and so, having lost all my patience for this game's nonsense, I went to turn off depth of field- and of course you can't disable that either. You can only turn it to Low. Ha. Ha ha.

Another choice that I really can't get behind is how the game locks your choice of Normal or Safe mode when you start the story. I began the game on "Normal" mode (in which the monsters can kill you) and quickly discovered that this was a mistake- not because they are especially difficult, but because being able to die to them adds nothing except potentially frustration and wasted time, and ultimately detracts from the actual horror of the experience.

But again, you can't switch to "Safe" mode mid-playthrough, so I had to live with my mistakes. I cursed this more than once when it demoted a scary monster to a logistical nuisance that I resented having to overcome yet again because I didn't do exactly what the game wanted and got killed.

So like... you CAN have an amazing time with this game, you absolutely can. And if you're reading this, you should! Install the mod (or edit the files) to turn off view bob, and choose Safe Mode when given the option, and you'll have a fine time.

But your ability to enjoy this game shouldn't hinge on whether you were lucky enough to stumble on this advice ahead of time. Playing this game, I feel like the devs were more interested in their silly little graphical tricks than whether or not I could actually experience their creation (never mind those players who are nausea-prone to begin with, who I suppose can simply go screw themselves for all the devs care). And that leaves me... really quite bitter, to be honest, in a way that overshadows all my other feelings about the game.

So, no. I don't recommend Soma, not after all that. Just because it's a horror game doesn't mean it should be physically unpleasant in real life to play it, and just because I can cheat my way around the issue doesn't mean I should have to.

140222678.review: When it comes to this absolute masterpiece of existential dread, the only negative I can think of is that you won't be able to find anything like it ever again once it's over. I expected "Amnesia/Penumbra: Underwater Edition," and it more-or-less delivers those same atmospheric hide-and-seek scares. But what I wasn't expecting was the mind-bending plot. Unlike Amnesia or other Frictional games, "SOMA" is scary long after you turn off the game. I think it's a game that would be scary without any monsters, because its most impactful terror is creeping and cerebral; it wraps itself around your mind and metastasizes. I don't think it would be an exaggeration to say something cliche like "It changes you." Also, the fear is of a flavor that I've never encountered anywhere else. It's made of questions about consciousness, existence, and the soul-- less "psychological horror" and more "philosophical." When you stare into the abyss, this is what stares back. Wow. Wow. WAU.

It will appear as though I have not finished this game but actually had to use the second executable (SomaNoSteam.exe) since the normal one had choppy performance. If you experience similar issues, try using this executable found within the game's local files.

The story is definitely the main draw here so you will be disappointed if you're expecting gameplay similar to Penumbra or Amnesia: The Dark Descent. Puzzles are strangely crammed into the last half, which were enjoyable, but I wish there were more throughout the first half. To start, this is probably my favorite horror game and one that I don't find particularly scary. At least not in the traditional sense. The encounters while unnerving, never really made me anxious like those in other games similar to this one. However, that is not why I love it. What makes this game special is pretty much every other aspect. The underwater setting, the characters, the story and lore. All our very well fleshed out, stuff that isn't too common within the state of modern day horror in video games. One aspect however, takes this game to the next level, and that's its focus on existentialist horror. I'm a bit biased, as I find this type to scare me the most, and also is the most fun to think about, its what lets this game stick with me after all this time (There is also a healthy splash of body horror which is a nice touch). You should play SOMA and you will remember it.

9.5/10

140062128.review:
[h1]SOMA - PROS & CONS[/h1]

Spoilers will be hidden in spoiler text.

[b]PROS[/b]

+Excellent audio design, graphics and lack of HUD allow for heavy immersion.
+Unique story concept.
+Makes you question what it means to be human.
+Makes you question your reality.
+Depressing and hopeless ambience that makes you feel as though nothing really matters anymore and everything is already over [spoiler](arguably true)[/spoiler].
+A gloomy world where you see people accepting their fate and humanity slowly dying in the form of audios, text logs and world details.
+Exploration does not hold your hand and requires you to pay close attention to your surroundings.
+Doesn't rely on jumpscares, though there are a few throughout the game.
+Brings many questions that slowly get answered as the game progresses.
+Subtle details that may not make sense at first glance.
+Often puts you in moral dilemmas.
+You are not "the chosen one". You are a random guy who somehow ended up in such a world, left to fend for themselves.
+High interactivity with the map and its objects make for interesting puzzles and adds even more immersion.
+Enemies have to be approached with different strategies.
+There are little buddha statues around the map to motivate you.
+World design makes for enviromental storytelling alongside the audio logs, notes and pictures you find throughout the game.
+Some of the exposition throughout the game is completely optional.
+[spoiler]The people you read about often appear later on and are actually important for the story.[/spoiler]
+[spoiler]Buddha statues might be symbolic for the themes of reincarnation in the game.[/spoiler]
+[spoiler]You get to play as Wall-e wearing a diving suit.[/spoiler]

[b]CONS[/b]

-Pretty linear story. 

[spoiler]It has only one ending, and the choices you make throughout the game never really come back to bite you. Because of this, many moral dilemmas are just there either to make you feel bad or not dilemmas at all since there is only one real choice that allows you to progress.[/spoiler]

-Certain enemy mechanics make the game more tedious than scary.

[spoiler]Blind enemies make your progress very sluggish by forcing you to crouch around and wait for them to go somewhere else. For whatever reason the devs LOVE this type of enemy, so much that you'll face them more times than any other enemy combined in the game. Sometimes, you'll face them several times in a row.

There is also a monster that attacks you if you look at it.

And they placed him in an area where you have to look around to solve the puzzle.[/spoiler]

-The game is fair. Too fair, to the point you don't feel like you're out of your comfort zone.

[spoiler]Why is this bad? Because it's not scary to know you'll always have a chance and will never be caught in a situation that's outside of your control.

For instance, enemies are either warned about or announced right before they become dangerous, as if the devs were on your shoulder yelling [b]"Woah, watch out!"[/b] and never letting you get caught off-guard (except for when Akers captures you).

The biggest offender of this is the glitching. There is a mechanic that glitches your screen the closer the monster is, allowing you to pinpoint their exact location. You will never [b]not[/b] see them coming. [/spoiler]

-HORROR'S OVER BABE! TIME FOR YOUR EXPOSITION DUMP!

-Game pacing is fairly predictable and makes it easy to tell when it's time for horror and when it's time to consume exposition.

-Characters are chatty and carrying a buddy around that dumps exposition on you (Catherine) makes the game not feel lonely and, consequently, less scary and mysterious.

-[spoiler][b]Catherine spoils the ending halfway through the game.[/b] 

Some may say this is foreshadowing, but nah. Foreshadowing is a subtle indication of what will happen, yet once you get transferred to your new body, Catherine literally explains exactly how the process works and what really happened to you. So no, it's not foreshadowing, it's straight up [b]the answer[/b]. 

A good example of foreshadowing would've been if you listened to Simon speaking in the other  room like they do ingame, but don't have Catherine do le funny exposition dump on you. Instead, leave the player to question why they heard their old body speaking in confusion and why it is still breathing. After all, the game gives you many hints as to how the process works anyway (before revealing it to you early).

-Because of this, the game essentially relies on you being a silly boy (like Simon) and forgetting what Catherine tells you in order for the ending plot twist to work.[/spoiler]


I would say that SOMA is not a horror game but rather a story driven game with horror as its secondary element. In my entire playthrough, I was only startled twice: [spoiler]when the no-look monster showed up the first time and when a random fish bit me out of nowhere while I was distracted. 

My favorite scary part was hearing Jin Yoshida's rapidly approaching footsteps pursuing me relentlessly around the corners, but when I confronted him he stood still and at that moment I assumed he was just another blind monster and my fear vanished almost instantly. Only later after beating the game and visiting the wiki did I discover what his mechanics were, but it's not like it mattered since he was easy to outrun anyway.[/spoiler]

It is absolutely an amazing game to play, especially during the night and while wearing headphones. But, do it with the mindset of immersing yourself into a mysterious world with a well written story, because the horror itself is pretty barebones. Like I said, a lot of the exposition is optional, but I'd say you should read it if you wish to understand the story properly.

I know the cons list may look bigger than the pros, but that's because there isn't much to say about the pros if I can't find any flaws in them. How can I give criticism to something that is already great as is? 

Don't forget that this is all my opinion, and you may have a much different experience of SOMA with your own interpretations. For me, this game is far more good than it is bad, and I don't regret a single penny.
