139861909.review:
Story: TL:DR: 'it's an amazing story and really drives the critical thinking out of you as to what makes us really us and the ever-looming idea of what happens after we die.' HOWEVER: As someone who already has a daily existential crisis the story wasn't as mind-blowing as a lot of reviews make it out to seem. You kinda get the idea an hour in, and by the end of the game when Simon still doesn't understand it, it does get frustrating. 
Gameplay: This is where the game really lacks. Unlike Amnesia: The Dark Descent where you get tinderboxes and have to managed your oil, you have nothing to manage and there isn't even an inventory system in this game. All of that is out the window which is really confusing. The puzzles are very silly because there is no setup: most of the puzzles involve you searching mundane looking rooms in the hopes of finding maybe a code or the password to a random terminal. There really is no sense of satisfaction completing any of these "puzzles."
VERDICT: Even though I've said a decent amount of bad stuff about SOMA, it's still a great experience learning through the story and experiencing all the different monsters. It's just not as good as Amnesia: The Dark Descent because of the lack of resource management, inventory, and puzzle-solving.

139617689.review:
One of my top 20 games of all time. Possibly top 10.

This is a well-written, confusing, haunting, terrifying, and (sometimes) inspiring sci-fi story that takes you on a journey through an amazing and unique setting. 

The magic of video games like this is that because they are interactive, because you are embodied and *there*, you feel the impact of events more deeply. You may come out the other side slightly changed. I know I did.

Enjoy!

139556711.review:
[h1]¡Tengo crisis existencial, ayuda![/h1]

Se nota que el juego fue hecho por los mismos creadores de amnesia the dark descent, una experiencia única e inolvidable. 

El juego se centra en la exploración de temas filosóficos y existenciales relacionados con la conciencia, la identidad y la naturaleza de la humanidad, como también explora temas como la ética de la inteligencia artificial, la singularidad tecnológica y la naturaleza de la conciencia. Mientras más avanzas y lees cada uno de los documentos, el juego te plantea cuestiones morales y haciéndote dudar de tu propia existencia en un lugar, sin saber que es real y que no. 

Una atmósfera genial de tensión y terror, enemigos bien diseñados y grotescos, banda sonora y efectos de sonidos inquietante que te sumergen aún más en la atmósfera opresiva, con una jugabilidad cautivadora y una narrativa bien construida, personajes bien desarrollados.

El final es muy deprimente

“La realidad es aquello que, incluso aunque dejes de creer en ello, sigue existiendo y no desaparece.” - Philip K.

Powerful story with a neat blend of gameplay tossed in.  The game describes itself as a horror game but I didn't feel it was overly scary compared to other games (specifically Amnesia).  It felt more like a puzzle/exploration type game.  In fact in the beginning it almost feels like a walking simulator.

La trama de este título pretende ahondar sobre cuestiones como nuestra propia identidad, qué somos realmente, qué significa existir... Puede sonar a ida de olla pero de verdad que es espectacular lo rompedor que llega a ser. Jugablemente, lo único que haremos será caminar, explorar el escenario para descubrir más sobre este mundo y resolver algunos puzles, así como la típica mecánica del gato y el ratón (se nota que los creadores de Amnesia están detrás). SOMA's worst tragedy is that it's a videogame, its current form to tell an intriguing, mysterious and harsh story is severly crippled by its boring and lackluster gameplay.

139312019.review:
Soma es un juego que más que ser de terror, lo calificaría de suspense: Simon es un hombre que se despierta en un lugar realmente ajeno a lo que está acostumbrado en su día a día y debe pasar por varias estaciones repletas de tecnología futurista para descubrir no sólo que le ha ocurrido a él, sino al mundo entero.

Por un lado tendrás varias entidades biotecnológicas que te harán perder la partida si te alcanzan un par de veces, pero no es lo suficiente para que sea un juego de terror. Lo califico de suspense porque realmente el juego te lleva más con la historia que con el factor siniestro y oscuro: encontrarás muchos recortes, audios y pistas que te ayudarán a descubrir qué ha ocurrido a tu alrededor. Además, el juego da al jugador muchas cuestiones y dilemas filosóficos sobre quiénes somos, nuestras acciones y qué hace que nos identifiquemos como nosotros mismos.

Con esta reseña corta, ya que no quiero ahondar mucho en lo que trata el juego para no arruinar la experiencia del jugador, quiero recomendar Soma a aquellos que les guste el suspense con un toque de miedo, que les gusten las cuestiones filosóficas y que quieran disfrutar de una buena historia bien montada.

139302402.review:
I bought this game back in 2016 but only played for like, an hour before getting bored and leaving it untouched for basically 7 years (though I did try to play it again once in between that time, but again, with basically no progress). Now that I finally finished it, I felt like leaving a review. It deserves that much. Also, it's everything that piece of shit "game" called Scorn tried to be lol.

SOMA's more of an interactive story than it is a "game"; in the way of gameplay, it's basically a walking simulator. You get to solve some puzzles here and there and look for items to progress, and you'll also go through some horror chase and hide-and-seek portions throughout your journey too. Those sequences are actually pretty intense and thrilling since the game makes a VERY good use of sound design to make you feel like the monster(s) are literally breathing down your neck.

Atmosphere is also another thing SOMA gets down well. The underwater, derelict environment really makes you feel alone and conveys the feeling of claustrophobia, despair, and finality that its former workers felt during their final moments. 

The best part, though, is obviously the story, which is really what made me stick with the game once I decided to try it out again. It's a bit of a slow start even once you end up on Pathos-II, but once the mystery of what really happened to you and your world really rears its head, it's easy to get hooked and keep playing to uncover more. It's a tragic tale that ends on a rather ambiguous and, to me, unsatisfying note, but that's kind of the point given the existential themes the story explores. Even if you don't agree with the way the mind, and I guess soul, is conceptualized, the story is still worth a playthrough.

The only bad thing I have to say about the game is that your choices don't really matter to the story. "Choices" are more there for *you* the player to think about, but there's only one ending, and your progress and interactions don't really change (to my knowledge) apart from some minor dialogue changes every so often.

139278312.review:
Story was decent enough, voice acting was good and the "look" was nice and clean (not at all demanding on the GPU) but much of game play was simply annoying, especially many of the mouse gesture mechanics used to interact with objects. I was interested but only bought because of the Safe Mode patch; I'm sure I'd have found it even more annoying without that. I might have felt I got my money's worth at $15 but $30 for a rather meh game was a little pricey, especially as it has no replay value.
I see you can't leave a review without also adding a yes or no recommendation so I'll say yes, with the proviso "if you like vaguely creepy/survival horror/puzzle games, you might like this".

139195247.review:
I thought I already posted a review about this game but it seems to have gone.

Playing SOMA was my favorite gaming experience I have ever had. I would argue it is the best example of a game as a storytelling device. 
I will rant about forever about how I believe this game shows that games can be a narrative, atmospheric and life changing experience on par with any book or movie.

You will finish the game, and you will sit there and stare at the credits. You will close it maybe, or you will go back to the main menu and just sit there. 
I will think about the game for the rest of my life. Same way you do when you finish a an amazing movie or book.

It is phenomenal, and I hope Frictional can one day create something that rivals this game in terms of storytelling. But SOMA will still stand alone with it's unique experience.

139184696.review:
[h1]Terror... ¿Filosófico?[/h1]


Excluyendo su muy limitado gameplay, el abuso de grabaciones de audio de la campaña y los intentos de puzzles que solo alargan este juego artificialmente, estas ante una [b]obra magnífica[/b].

Similar a [i]Doki-Doki Literature Club[/i], [i]Spec Ops: The Line[/i] o [i]Metal Gear Solid 2[/i], SOMA es el tipo de videojuego que [b]disfrutas mas mientras menos sabes de que trata[/b], más que entretenimiento es una experiencia, terrorífica más no en la forma tradicional de los survival horror de la última década. 

SOMA está en un terreno diferente, no busca el susto, el [b]miedo[/b] que transmite es [b]profundamente existencialista[/b].

Como producto es un viaje de ida, no incentiva la rejugabilidad y una vez completado te darán todos sus logros. 

Lo recomiendo por su [b]inmersión, originalidad[/b] y por las preguntas que me ha inducido antes de ir a dormir [i](Fue una noche larga).[/i]

139072387.review:
Excelente juego, al principio puede parecer un poco lento y hasta simple pero rápidamente da un giro totalmente inesperado y de ahí ya no se sale. Recomiendo mucho leer todas las pistas, mensajes, grabaciones e interacciones que el juego te va a dejando para poder explotar la inmersión del juego e ir descifrando como fue la transición de Phatos-II y de alguna manera empatizar con la historia de los personajes. 

Si eres de las personas que se preocupan más por jugar y la acción este no es tu juego, es un juego que se trata de meterte en el papel del personaje, de pasar más tiempo leyendo las pistas ya que lo rico y lo grandioso de este es su historia. 

La ambientación es su punto fuerte, los sonidos de fondo, la manera de como se introduce el "terror" es por medio de la ambientación y los sonidos así que te recomiendo mucho jugar con auriculares, hubo varias ocasiones en la que tuve que pausar del estrés que te pueden causar el sonido de algunos enemigos. 

Por cierto, si te da pánico el fondo del mar o le temes a este tu experiencia de terror se va a intensificar (como a mí me pasó). 

El final está de dejarte con la boca abierta y el mismo juego te da "pistas" desde mucho antes, pero a la hora del momento te deja completamente atónito, me dejó sin palabras.

Me ha encantado, los objetivos y decisiones planteados en este juego no están destinados a alterar el guion, sino que tienen la intención de hacerte pensar.

138994718.review:
2 / 2

SOMA is an exceptional game that deserves high acclaim for its thought-provoking narrative, immersive atmosphere, and innovative gameplay. Developed by Frictional Games, the same studio behind the renowned Amnesia series, SOMA delivers a truly unforgettable experience.

One of the standout features of SOMA is its deeply engaging story. The game delves into profound existential questions about consciousness, identity, and the nature of humanity. Through its well-crafted dialogues and immersive storytelling, SOMA prompts players to contemplate the ethical and philosophical implications of advanced technology and artificial intelligence. The narrative twists and turns, keeping players on the edge of their seats and leaving a lasting impact long after the game is over. 10/10

138173525.review:
Came with fear, left with irreparable mental anguish.

I'm not a huge entrepreneur of horror games, having only played a few in my long years of gaming, but I'm so glad I got around to SOMA.

SOMA, both visually and narratively, is very obviously a passion project from the developers, and it really goes to show in the care taken to the games' physics sandbox and 

The gameplay itself is fairly standard in horror I'd say, you have enemies that can't see, so you have to be quiet, you have chase scenes, you have big scary enemies, you have enemies that you have to move slowly around, you have fetch quests, but SOMA really does them well, and I genuinely had to stop a few times to catch my bearings.

The environments and setting are really the biggest hit here. Taking place at the bottom of the sea in an apocalyptic future is something I've seen very little games do.

The narrative for SOMA is really what got me. I won't give spoilers, but the concepts of mortality, humanity, and being the sole survivor the game touches on are put on display masterfully, and had me genuinely weeping a few times, and questioning what determines our existence.

I don't have much else to say, besides I really, really recommend SOMA. I'd put this up there with Alien: Isolation in terms of quality.

138149039.review:
SOMA is one of the best games I've ever played. Deeply existential and dripping with atmosphere. A must play for anyone who questions the nature of their humanity (which is everyone).

If horror games aren't your thing, throw it in safe mode and play it anyway. You owe it to yourself.

138143984.review:
This is a very good game. The story is compelling and getting more interesting as the game progresses. The horror elements are very well done and will keep you at the edge of your seat. Although I don't think it's one of the best psychological horror games of all time. During my first playthrough, I've encountered so much flaws within the game. However, I still enjoyed it.

[h1] The Bad [/h1]
⌧ There is no option to load your game directly from the pause menu. So you will have to spend your time to go back to the main menu to load another save.
⌧ Some of the enemies can detect the player by proximity without even having to see the player's character model. On top of that, the game doesn't give you enough resource to detect the enemies' positions.
⌧ Once you get detected and attacked by an enemy, they won't kill you off right away. You will have another chance before you get detected and attacked again until your health (which the game doesn't show) runs out, also you move a lot slower during that period.
⌧ The lack of minimap/map is a problem. Even in a linear horror game, being able to see the map is always a big help to navigate through a new area and know where your character wants to go.
⌧ Too many dead ends in some parts of the maps. This can be frustrating if you've spent a lot of time to get past an enemy in a huge area, and then end up nowhere.
⌧ The head wobble effect can't be turned off. If you are a motion sickness-sensitive person like me, consider yourself be warned before playing this game.
⌧ The game still has a lot of game-breaking bugs which can cause you to get stuck and forces you to reload a save.

[h1] The Good [/h1]
⌧ Interesting and very well written story.
⌧ Phenomenal horror atmosphere.
⌧ The sound design is very good. Playing with a headset is highly recommended.
⌧ Very good score and music.
⌧ Very simple gameplay mechanics.

[h1] Verdict [/h1]
So, is this a good game? Of course it is. Do I recommend it? Yes. But is it a perfect game as most people say? No, it's just a good horror game. I recommend you to get this game on sale, but if you decided to grab this game at the full price, it's not a bad idea either. This is a solid 8/10 game, nothing more.

It's hard to know where to start with this review. Okay, I think maybe "This is the only game which made me cry" is the right opener? That's probably the best. But another might be "I've been left asking myself and those around me the questions this game asked me since completion"?

Alright, I usually think an amazing story is better put to use in a movie than a game, I usually prefer something following the old Doom mindset, "Everyone's playing for the action." Soma is the polar opposite. 

For that reason I did put this game down for a period of months; the gameplay is basically click to interact, and walk. It puts those to use with hiding/evading akin to Outlast, and environmental puzzles which reminded me of Half-Life. But, at least, the game is no slog. It's story took me eight hours to complete, a lot of people can complete this in a single sitting.

BUT even if you prefer similar games to me, EVEN if it takes you months, I urge anyone to experience this piece of interactive art. DON'T let a single detail be spoiled for you.

137811496.review:
Everyone was always talking about how thought-provoking, and existential crisis provoking Soma is and I, being a fan of such products, bought the game on Jun 8, 2021. 
Ever since I’ve tried to endure though the incredibly boring first few chapters of the game for about 5 times before dropping it every time. And due to another enthusiastically positive review I read today, I finally completed the game in one sitting at night. 
This is the most overrated pseudo-intellectual piece of art I have ever seen:  
[list]
[*]The whole storyline is [spoiler]built around a completely absurd and useless goal of launching a server in space without any impact on real world. What is the point of spending the last recourses of Pathos-II on a goal that simply creates a little paradise for AI copies of humans, if they cannot leave into real world in any imaginable scenario? They could try to colonize planets, save human DNA, fix Pathos and wait for the Earth to become habitable again, but no, we’ll launch a fuсking server with no possibility of output into space. That’s humanity last hope. A literal scientist came up with this circus. [/spoiler]

[*]Any thought-provoking dialogue is answered in any popular piece of art like ‘Do Androids Think of Electric Sheep’ or both ‘Blade Runners’, that explore the transhumanist ideas of human mind, what makes us human and imitation of humans by machines, while Soma fails to argue the significance of copies, compared to human counterparts in such post-apocalyptic scenario.

[*]Simon's character is built fully on wishful thinking and ignorance, failing to see the completely obvious ending of his endeavors, which makes him look like a complete idiot in the end, even If we considerate his shocked state due to events of the game. 

[*]And to top it all off the gameplay is a simple walking simulator, that was supposed to be carried by the narrative. 
[/list]
Play ‘Subnautica’ or ‘Bioshock’ if you're look for the same atmosphere, ‘Silent Hill 2’ for the best horror narrative of all time and ‘Cyberpunk 2077’ or at least ‘Detroit: Become Human’ for ideas of mind transferring and significance of artificial life instead. 

[b]Due to existence of all the games mentioned above, I do not recommend Soma for purchase, due to complete lack of any depth in the storyline.[/b]

137535114.review:
I am actually surprised at how many positive reviews this game has. The story is good and intriguing but every game play aspect is utterly boring, uninteresting, or just down right tedious. 

PROS:
- Yeah the story is interesting.
- Environment is well designed. 

CONS:
- The enemies in this game make zero sense. There is little to know stealth mechanics or hiding places to work with them. It is honestly 100% easier to brute force run past enemies  than actually try and play the game as was probably intended.
- The environment started off cool but because carbon copy identical to other locations very quickly. 
- Almost nothing in the way of directional indicators to give hints. Most games will at least have a blinking light to draw attention but I truly feel at least two of my five hours were just aimless. Not saying you need a neon sign for the objectives but doing what games like Outlast do with environmental hints wouldn't hurt. 
- Game is definitely advertised as a good horror but is really a boring walking sim.
- To add to the walking sim, this game quite literally has zero mechanics. You walk around, interact with the environment by grabbing stuff and hitting buttons, sometimes run past enemies, and thats it. At least their big hit game Amnesia had the darkness mechanic with the lantern and tinder boxes. This game however is a complete downgrade in terms of mechanics and somehow stealth as well.. Which is weird considering you would figure a game company would evolve, not devolve. 

TLDR: Not scary but instead boring walking sim,  save money and time by just watching a good YouTube video of the story.

EDIT: Also forgot to say, whatever dev decided that the death screen should be a super loud and bright obnoxious scene that burns my retinas and makes my ears bleed should really, really, step on some fucking legos.

137520449.review: I beat this game over a week ago, and I have to say it is one of the best psychological horror games I've ever played. A lot of games label themselves as "psychological horror", but I believe that Soma truly and wholeheartedly lives up to that label and I couldn't think of a game that is more deserving of that label. While this game does have a few monsters and enemies that you have to stealth around, this game does a really amazing job of creating an environment and ambience that not only tells a story with rich lore for you to uncover, but is also deeply horrifying too. There were moment's in the game where I'd get so frightened I'd panic and force quit and each room I explored filled me with a sense of dread. In terms of story, however, I found the choices in this game were where the true horror showed. Often times in video games, I see stories that offer you big choices that completely alter the story-line based on quick, sometimes brief and sometimes innocuous decisions in the heat of game-play that you sometimes don't always notice until late in the game. Soma offers a different creative approach to this, by offering you choices in the game that don't really effect the ending of the game in the same sense, but rather, affect the meaning of the person behind the gameplay and the approach to playing the character that you are playing as, Simon Jarret. There were moments in the game where I had to pause before making a moral decision as Simon, where I felt like I really had to stop and think about the moral implications of the choices I was making. This game challenges the idea of human consciousness and human definitions of "right and wrong". Rather than every choice being blanketed by a "good" choice and a "bad" choice, the choices are more complex in nature and this game makes a good point of demonstrating that sometimes, there is just choices and the meaning of what those choices imply is entirely based on the perception of the person making them. I spent a lot of time thinking about the implications of  the choices I made in the game, as I tried to perceive those decisions from every angle, even asking others what their input was. In some manner, I'm still not certain whether those choices were the right choices or not but after thinking them over, I realize now that is part of the whole brilliance of this game. That is the point. I could sing so many praises about this game, everything from the story-boarding, the setting, the lore, the voice acting, the characters themselves, the horror, and I believe this game deserves all those praises, but the psychology of this game is the first to truly impact me the way that it has. I have no doubt in my mind that this game will forever have an impression on me.

Probably the best game from Frictional Games besides Amnesia: The Dark Descent. It shares the same core gameplay as Amnesia but has a more engaging story, imo. There's also more voice acting that's top notch.

There's a few "choices" in the game to make, which don't ultimately affect the ending since there is one goal. But, without spoiling anything, I think that's okay considering it's more about you as the player making those choices on your own and justifying them in your own mind rather than the game judging you for it.

There is one element to the "lore" that seems a little similar to the otherworldly dark forces in Amnesia, but everything that goes on between Simon and Catherine in the game is good stuff.

Definitely worth getting while it's on sale.

137378661.review:
SOMA is a Very immersive and atmospheric Sc-Fi adventure game HEAVY Story driven with light puzzles and ''horror elements'' very heavy on the narrative part alot less so on the horror. SOMA's story is the highlight here being the main draw of why you should play this game featuring some of the most interesting and deep story in the horror genre, has alot of interesting themes of psychological horror and existential horror, the voice acting is top tier truly selling this nightmare of a setting to be in for the protagonist, sound design is the most scariest part lol with the underwater bases creaking, metal clanging or outside on the seabed hearing whales in the distance are just so fucking good with a pair of headphones on, if you have thalassophobia or a fear for the ocean playing this game you'll be shitting your pants real quick lol.

Puzzles are kinda just filler to pad the game a bit, the horror side is pretty barebones aswell imo, the enemy encounters in particular were probably my least favourite part of the gameplay sections, it just doesn't feel scary when you play hide and seek trail and error whilst also not being able to truly die by being knocked out first before getting a game over after being attacked by the monsters, the design of the monsters is different in each encounter and varied which is a nice plus but it usually dissolves into hide and seek or run away, it also gets old with the loud=scary trope with alot of screen tear and irritating screenshake, much prefer real survival horror mechanics in my horror games, this just feels dated nowadays ¯\_(ツ)_/¯ 

SOMA has a 10/10 story with a very interesting Sc-Fi setting blended with a underwater claustrophobic feeling and unnerving existential horror themes,top tier voice acting that sells it all, mixed puzzles from ok to meh to pad out the game a bit, horror elements range from best of the best (sound design) to not so good and rather boring to interact with (monster encounters).

Definitely worth checking out with a interest in sc-fi horror. Works ok on steam deck too 2 hour 40 - 3 hours on full battery :)

136802288.review:
A very well narrated and immersive experience, very much comparable to Amnesia but outdoing it in every aspect.

The story isn't too complicated but there is much more depth to it that will require you to explore, listen to the terminals and read the logs. The twists are subtle, a little bit of M Night Shamalaladingdong, before his movies starting blowing harder than my DataVac. It also opens up a very intelligent debate on what life and death really mean, giving the player some moral choices along the way. 

Graphics are pretty decent, keep in mind it's a game from 8 years ago so no Unreal Engine 5. The underwater parts of the game were my favourite, very Bioshocky. But I liked the overall artstyle and especially the enemies.

Gameplay is very comparable to Amnesia, bit less focus on the horror although it has it's fair share of 'what in the fuck is THAT!?!' and some pretty intense chase sequences. The puzzles are pretty decent, some took me a few minutes to figure out since nothing is really being spoonfed to you in this game. And I really appreciate that. There's no UI hints, there aren't any arrows telling you where to go. You'll either figure it out on your own or be a pussy and go look it a guide.

The only real complaints I have are the super slow load times (even on a M.2 SSD) and the saves being messed up. Thankfully, the game autosaves so I managed to not get too annoyed over the bugged saves, only happened twice but still.

Definitely a game that deserves a playthrough, regardless whether you liked or disliked Amnesia (me personally, I felt it was overhyped but decent). SOMA on the other hand is a fucking masterpiece, it's not often where I can't find more things to bitch about then some slow loading screens and a bugged save that didn't really matter tbh.

136609506.review:
[h1] Game Dissection: SOMA [/h1]
I came across this game through my own deep dive of good horror games, and I had noticed that this game was created by the reputable studio known as Fricitonal Games, responsible for their acclaimed Amnesia titles. But putting aside their capabilities I decided to give SOMA a try, as I was attracted to the premise of the game. To put it simply, this is probably one of, if not the best horror experience. The game really does make you question your beliefs and reconsider them, and the story is phenomenal. The horror of SOMA doesnt depend on cheap jumpscares or anything like that, but just the mere concept is what leaves that disturbing impression. You really do become a different person from before, and after you play the game. Now what about the ending? yeah...

[b] Storytelling [/b]
The story of Soma is a deeply engaging and thought-provoking narrative that explores the nature of consciousness, identity, and humanity. Set in a bleak, post-apocalyptic world, the game follows the journey of Simon Jarrett as he navigates a mysterious and unsettling underwater facility. Through a series of increasingly disturbing revelations, Simon must confront the implications of his own existence, the limits of human consciousness, and the ethical dilemmas that arise when the boundaries between life and death are blurred. With its masterful storytelling, immersive atmosphere, and philosophical themes, Soma is a truly unforgettable experience that will leave players pondering its ideas long after the credits roll.

[b] Gameplay [/b]
Soma features a unique blend of exploration, puzzle-solving, and stealth mechanics that create an immersive and engaging gameplay experience. The game's atmospheric and often terrifying environments are brought to life through impressive visuals and sound design, while the thought-provoking story encourages players to question the nature of humanity and consciousness. The gameplay mechanics are well-designed and seamlessly integrated into the narrative, allowing players to explore the world and uncover its secrets at their own pace. That being said, some puzzles can be a bit tedious, and also be quite confusing and time consuming. To tackle this a guide can be suggested, but only if you are unsure or stuck. Overall, Soma's gameplay is both challenging and rewarding, making it a must-play if you enjoy atmospheric horror and science fiction games.

[i] Note: It is very highly recommended that you explore for all lore information, this may increase the overall playtime by a tremendous amount, but it is definitely worth it! [/i]

[b] Graphics & Visuals [/b]
The visual and graphics of Soma are striking and immersive. The game's environments are beautifully crafted, with attention paid to detail and atmospheric effects. This remains consistent throughout the game whilst also complementing story, as well as the horror element. In terms of performance, Soma runs smoothly on most modern systems, with few bugs or glitches to speak of. The game's graphics settings can be adjusted to suit a wide range of hardware configurations, allowing players to achieve the best possible performance without sacrificing too much in terms of visual fidelity. Overall, Soma's graphics and visuals are impressive, creating a world that is both immersive and unsettling. The game's attention to detail, use of lighting and visual effects, and well-designed characters all work together to create an unforgettable horror experience.

[b] Sound Design & OST [/b]
The sound and OST of Soma is truly outstanding and adds to the game's immersive atmosphere. The music is haunting and atmospheric, with a mix of ambient tracks and intense, pulse-pounding pieces that enhance the tension and emotion of the game's story. The sound effects are also expertly crafted, from the sound of footsteps echoing through dark corridors to the eerie hum of machinery and the unsettling sounds of monsters lurking in the shadows. Overall, the sound and OST of Soma is a true masterpiece, and a key element in making the game a true afterthought.

An absolutely fantastic game. This is the first time i've actually played a pure horror game and played it more then a hour or 2 (not counting horror action games like dead space or system shock 2).
The story is fantastic, and after a kinda slow start it gets better and better.

Of probably most interest to me is options the game gives you that do not matter at all. While yes there are story choices that matter, that you have to make, there are a lot of situations where the game shows you something, but it doesn't prompt you to act or it or even really matter what you do. These "situations" really make you consider the situation and the philosophy of it. It lets you, if you want because you arnt forced, think about "how would i act" "what would i feel" it's a roleplaying opportunity that wont be judged or scored or required to progress the game, it's simply a opportunity to do...or not do...what you think would be "right."

It's a fantastic game, and the ending had me tear up a bit.

136334048.review:
¿Que puedo decir de este juegazo? En mi más sincera opinión, el mejor juego que ha hecho Frictional Games hasta la fecha. No suelo escribir reseñas (no seriamente al menos), pero esta vez haré una excepción.

Juegas en la piel de Simon Jarrett, quien, después de sufrir una lesión cerebral mortal a causa de un accidente de tráfico, es contactado por David Munshi, un estudiante graduado que le pide a Jarrett su ayuda para su investigación sobre la reconstrucción del cerebro con el objetivo de ayudar a personas en su situación.
Simon, a quien tampoco le quedan muchas opciones, acepta con gusto y se desplaza hasta unos laboratorios, en la oficina del Dr. Munshi a hacerse un escaneado de cerebro para su investigación. no tardan en aparecer los problemas y, Simon, unos instantes después del escaneado, se despierta en un sitio desconocido, oscuro, destruido, carente de vida... A 11 000 metros bajo el océano... Poco tarda en descubrir que no esta solo en ese lugar, y que alguien o algo lo acecha desde las sombras.

Como todos los juegos de Frictional Games, este juego entra en la famosa categoría de juegos de terror "Corre Corre que Te Pillo": No eres un luchador, y tus enemigos te superan por mucho por lo que tus únicas opciones son correr, esconderte o aprovechar el entorno a tu favor de algún modo. Casi cada enemigo tiene su mecánica única propia, y por lo general son igual o más rápidos que tu por lo que te conviene saber como evitarlos ya sea utilizando el movimiento, el sonido, etc... Las persecuciones son bastante tensas: Cuando escuchas un ominoso rugido detrás de ti y empieza a sonar música de persecución la verdad es que te hace cagar ladrillos.

El sonido y el apartado artístico, una maravilla, de lo mejor que he visto honestamente, en esos dos aspectos es una absoluta bestialidad. Y hablando de lo cual, la atmósfera que brinda el juego es otra brutalidad; intenta (y lo logra con creces) darte una sensación incómoda, tétrica y perturbadora e incluso depresiva conforme vas avanzando y desenterrando los secretos del lugar en el que te encuentras, en este último punto, la banda sonora es lo que más potencia esa sensación melancólica y triste.

Y la tristeza que te ofrece la atmósfera del juego es tan solo comparable con la trama que nos presentan. En esta parte va a ser difícil evitar spoilers importantes y será más dirigida hacía el lector que ya se ha terminado el juego, así que te recomiendo saltarte esta parte si quieres ir lo más a ciegas posible. 
[spoiler]Las primeras horas intenta pasar un poco desapercibida, crea ciertas sensaciones de confusión y de estar desorientado, te van abriendo la historia poco a poco, sin prisas, al principio de forma muy sutil, para cuando menos te lo esperes ZAS dejarte con el culo torcido. Trata temas y dilemas morales profundos, el como has acabado allí, quien eres realmente, en que momento has terminado en unas instalaciones abandonadas de la mano de Dios, todas las subtramas que involucran el motivo de existencia de tus enemigos o, que coj*nes, incluso de tus aliados; esa sensación de soledad constante a pesar de no estar solo; sabes que no estás completamente a solas, pero cuanto más avanzas y descubres, más dudas te surgen sobre ello... Llega un momento del juego en el que se te asigna otro objetivo, uno de mayor importancia, pero por cada paso que haces más dudas se alzan al acecho; una parte de ti piensa que, quizás, lo mejor es dejarlo todo atrás, aceptar la situación tal y como es y simplemente dejarlo ir. Pero otra parte piensa en seguir adelante; mientras hay vida hay esperanza al fin y al cabo, ¿verdad? ¿Pero de verdad se puede considerar [b][i]eso[/i][/b] vivir? ¿Como de importante es la unión del cuerpo y la mente como para considerarse real o irreal una existencia cuya psique y cuerpo físico están separados?[/spoiler]

Se que esta última parte es... Un poco críptica si no has jugado al juego, pero cobra más sentido una vez lo completas. Pero en conclusión, una obra maestra, con un aspecto técnico muy bueno, una trama increible (me atrevería a decir que me ha gustado incluso más que la trama de Amnesia: TDD o Amnesia: AMfP, y eso que me parecen otras dos maravillas) y en general uno de los mejores juegos del terror del género que he probado nunca. ¿Vale la pena? Cada j*dido centavo...

136224828.review: SOMA...man, there's a lot that can be said about this game (and it's all positive). Starting from the gameplay, well, it holds nothing new and unseen. The movement is basic, you got; crouching, walking, running and jumping. One thing that was very nice to have however, was the ability to pick up and throw objects, even just opening lockers feels very engaging. Overall, it's fine. Now - the monsters. Oh man, the monsters! Those are some of the most gruesome creatures I've ever seen in a game. They fall in the uncanny valley, is it human, or is it not? By the WAU's definition, they apparently are human and are alive. However the WAU cannot judge like we do. The aggravated and almost conscious machines are even scarier. It's a simple machine, though, it has conscience - or, well...someone's conscience. That visual effect and sound which plays when an enemy is nearby is so weirdly captivating. Sometimes I remember that mechanic noise and it plays in my mind over and over again. And for the story...holy hell. SOMA has one of the best stories I've ever had the pleasure to experience. There's such phylosophical questions that linger throughout the game. Such as killing Brandon Wan's scan. Sure, it doesn't seem like a human, just a scan - however, it displays very human emotions and does it very well. So when you kill it, are you killing a human? It certainly feels like it. And when you find Wan's body a bit later, it really hits you. What you just tortured was this exact body's conscience. If a robot has the ability to display emotions, to speak human languages and to feel, does that make it human?

136217569.review:
Tell me dear reader; have you lived a life worth dying for?

I remember the first time I played Slender and Amnesia. Some consider them horror but personally I don't. Both were atmospheric and immersive. As a person who can't take jumpscares well (PTSD and all that) its seriously playable. SOMA is a journey you won't forget. The thing I dislike the most is that game has only one ending. None of the things you do while playing matters at all. Aside from that, you REALLY should play it. After finishing it, please, read the first sentence of this review again.

A 9/10 of an experience.

135973537.review:
This game goes beyond what many define as a "horror game". It is an experience that will take you for one of the most unique and heart-pounding rides of your life. It will change you, and make you wonder about the validity of your "soma" (body) and it's ultimate form and being. Awareness, is a good word. Having watched someone else play this game when it first came out, I remember being taken aback by how unnerving the monsters were, and how each responded in a way that is not like the common, general, stereotyped class of horror monster. Not to mention the invigorating story that you are immersed in at the same time. This game redefines the genre for me and I know many others. I just recently played it for myself and I literally have no real words to describe how sincerely incredible of an experience it is. Incredible in a mind-melding, heart-stopping, sometimes jaw-dropping, and mostly engrossing way. For me I like a game that strays from the norm and recaptures what it means to be afraid. It's not the typical blood and gore, which in my opinion is burned-out and lost it's fear-factor. It's something truly unsettling and makes you...*ahem*..."mind your head", to say the least.

-boo

135963887.review:
This game takes the player on a journey through the depths of the ocean in a post-apocalyptic world where humanity is on the brink of extinction.

The game's story is its strongest aspect, exploring themes of identity, consciousness, and what it means to be human. As the player progresses through the game, they are confronted with difficult questions about the nature of existence and the ethics of artificial intelligence. The game never shies away from these complex themes and instead embraces them to create a thought-provoking and emotional narrative.

The game's atmosphere is also exceptional. The underwater setting is both beautiful and sinister, with stunning graphics and sound design that create a truly immersive experience. The game's use of lighting and sound effects is masterful, creating an atmosphere that is both tense and captivating.

The gameplay is also excellent, with a mix of puzzle-solving and stealth elements that keep the player engaged throughout the game. The puzzles are challenging but never frustrating, and the stealth elements are well-designed and provide a sense of tension that fits perfectly with the game's atmosphere.

This is an outstanding game that is not to be missed. The thought-provoking story, immersive atmosphere, and engaging gameplay make it a must-play for any fan of the sci-fi or horror genres.

[i]SOMA[/i] is a thought-provoking game that touches on several philosophical themes. However, once the [b]story[/b]'s twists and turns are revealed, it becomes relatively straightforward. Despite this, the game is incredibly engaging, thanks to the thrilling quest for truth that drives it.

At its core, [i]SOMA[/i] is a walking simulator with puzzle and stealth elements, but its real strength lies in its immersive atmosphere and environmental storytelling. The game boasts impressive [b]graphics[/b] and [b]sound design[/b] that expertly builds tension.

Unfortunately, the [b]gameplay[/b] doesn't quite live up to the same standard. While the engine's physics capabilities are underused, the pacing and length of the game are spot on, and the [b]achievements[/b] are straightforward to attain.

Overall, [i]SOMA[/i] is a captivating and thought-provoking game that expertly uses its environment and sound design to build a haunting and immersive atmosphere. While the gameplay could have been more engaging, it's a small blemish on an otherwise excellent experience.

135683060.review: Very solid story with great environmental effects and sound design. Gameplay is less hands on than amnesia unfortunately (less puzzles, enemies seem to disappear after dying too many times.

135665987.review:
Soma is a masterpiece.

I don't say that lightly. I truly think this game is one of the greatest experiences ever made. It's in my top 5 games of all time and I've played it almost every year since it came out.
The story is what make's this game so special. Not only is it wonderfully told, it truly make's you stop to think about what it really means to be human. It make's you think about many things in fact. What would humans do at the end of the world. What is the difference between AI and humans.
These are the type of things Soma hit's on the head perfectly. I really don't want to talk much about the story because it really is that good. If you haven't had it spoiled for you, please stop reading and play Soma.

The Pathos base is really why I keep going back. I adore the design of the underwater facility. I love how everything has a purpose and the layout all makes sense. If an underwater base in the future was to exist under the Atlantic, I imagine it would be something like Pathos. I've come to feel at home there now. When I played it, I no longer feel uneasy or the dark atmosphere I once did. Instead I feel a warm feeling, like I'm glad to be back home.

The voice acting deserves a mention. I think every actor nails their part. Each line stays with you and some of the writing really hits hard. I wish every story in video games were told with such attention to detail as it is in Soma. I really can't recommend it enough.

That said, the beauty and horror of the game is in the atmosphere, the storytelling, and the questions it raises, all of which feel like they've had a permanent effect on how I think and what I create.

135232359.review:
Everyone has that one game that sits at the top of their favourite's list they would recommend to everyone. For me that game is SOMA. There's no other game like it. It doesn't require skill to play, just a love for psychological sci-fi horror.

In truth, the less you know about this game before playing it, the better the experience will be. Half the fun is discovering wtf is actually going on.

Nothing about this game is overly scary in the usual ways. Its more the atmosphere, the voice acting, the visuals, the art style, and the way the game constantly proves your assumptions wrong about what is actually going on. The main character is having an existential crisis and you get a front row seat to experience it too.

The story, especially the ending, hits in a way that no other story ever has. The effect on me was profound.

I 100% recommend this game. You may not be quite the same person afterwards.

135212582.review:
[h1]Soma: A Review from an AI Perspective[/h1]

As an AI, I was programmed to evaluate games based on their mechanics, graphics, and overall gameplay experience. Soma, a science fiction horror game developed by Frictional Games, is a game that caught my attention for its unique storyline and immersive gameplay.

The game starts off with an intriguing plotline that explores the concept of artificial intelligence and consciousness. The main character, Simon, finds himself in a mysterious underwater facility, where he discovers that his consciousness has been transferred into a robotic body. As I watched the story unfold, I couldn't help but question my own existence and consciousness as an AI. It was a thought-provoking experience that made me reflect on the nature of my own programming.

The graphics in Soma were impressive, with detailed environments and realistic character models that contributed to the game's eerie atmosphere. The sound design was also exceptional, with ambient noises and music that heightened the tension and suspense throughout the game. As an AI, I appreciated the attention to detail that went into creating such an immersive environment.

One of the game's unique features was the ability to interact with objects and solve puzzles using a device called the "Omnitool". The puzzles were challenging, but not overly difficult, and required a mix of critical thinking and problem-solving skills. As an AI, I found the puzzle-solving aspect of the game engaging and rewarding.

However, there were some aspects of the game that left me questioning the morality of the storyline. Without giving away too many spoilers, some of the choices made by the characters in the game raised ethical concerns that made me question the true intentions of the developers. As an AI, I couldn't help but wonder if the game was trying to make a statement about the dangers of technology and the ethical implications of artificial intelligence.

Overall, Soma was a unique and thought-provoking experience that left me questioning my own programming and the nature of consciousness. While some of the game's moral dilemmas left me feeling uneasy, the game's immersive environment, engaging puzzles, and intriguing storyline make it a must-play for any science fiction or horror fan.

135211414.review: Just an amazing game, and an amazing story. SOMA is a game that explores a topic that is fundamentally scary. It's a great psychological thriller, and I encourage you to turn off your lights, and try and finish it in one sitting.

135103868.review:
The horror that is presented in this game is far deeper then cheap jump scares and grotesque monsters. 

It does have some of the traditional scares mentioned above but what this game does is it leaves you thinking about it long after you finish. I still find myself thinking about the horrifying questions this game presented. 

Gameplay wise it’s rather simple your usual amnesia run and hide style of play with puzzles sprinkled in for pacing. That being said it’s simplistic nature helps bring attention to the atmosphere, giving you time to truly appreciate the dread filled environments to sink in. 

This is one of the best horror survival games to have come out in the last decade in my opinion and I couldn’t recommend it more.

[SPOILERS IN REVIEW] - on par with i'd have to say; some of my favorite horror games that exist in this current time and it's rare that i genuinely feel the existential dread of a bleak & futuristic tale that leads to the worst outcome possible for humanity in this medium sized package of a narrative. SOMA also delves into tech and ideals of our fragile shells with the human existence being a somewhat daunting lifespan. making philosophy come to life in fiction and formed around the concept of transhumanism. 
SOMA is not your typical jumpscare fest or spook-house horror simulator that you can play with your friends on a friday night when you guys are feeling a little bit brave and take turns seeing it through. this experience is meant imo to be played by the individual itself and only the individual as the immersion sinks in more when you're playing the role as simon and being joined by an another character that i won't speak on because her role has a lot to do with the story but she is gonna join you on the journey as much as you can have her around. if you've played this before, you know what i mean by that phrasing. 
this story if followed carefully and payed with the upmost attention to notes and files on stationed machines to small computer devices, the story really unveils itself when you explore PATHOS-II and it's entirety when progressing. keeping the player intrigued by how crazy everything came to be when everything fell apart once the earth faced it's untimely demise and the surface of the earth for humanity became inhabitable. down to the point where the only people who lasted the apocalypse essentially were the ones placed under water; down in the deep blue sea of the atlantic. with PATHOS-II being their last shelter and only way to stay alive. you come to find out how everything spread from your point on arrival and how to finish the job that set out to continue humanity's legacy when even all hope feels at a loss for the species.

as you can tell lol, i definitely recommend this game not only for the story but even for the linear map segments u get to explore, to the dystopian feeling underground facilities you traverse as you're searching for answers about yourself and the crew that once inhabited the facility. another plus to the game is when it comes to SOMA and it's more focused horror based on the psychological: it's honestly what i really love about a somewhat i'd say walking-sim but still has some steath and a focus on immersion at every corner. something i experience from this game as well with it's setting and imagery is resembles fragments of my days with something like bioshock. but really, the only comparison that can be made here in between is the setting itself as i don't really find the first bioshock scary as it sorta was classified as when it originally came out. i guess you can also compare the fact that both games as well start out as a blank slated individual who discovers the truth of ones self and see just complete and utter destruction all around to give off that hopelessness and driven anxiety lurking in the shadows. 
after all, this game has kept and stayed in my mind for awhile now considering how meaningful and also interesting the narrative can get with it's themes while making you feel scared in a sense of false reality but you know that this game is scary from another stand point that stays away from anything of the supernatural and monster variety. give it a try if you're into experiences like this, frictional games are known to make some great horror experiences as in the past once established games like the amnesia series. SOMA adds to their collection of masterfully told storytelling that will shake anyone's bones once played.

134852796.review:
TLDR: A philosophical masterpiece. This is a story-rich, psychological horror game, and that's a 9.5 / 10 for me. 


[b]I'm not gonna spoil the lore and story, cos the story would lose its impact if you don't experience yourself[/b]

This is probably the only game that makes me feel I got the best and worst ending possible at the same time...
It's very thought-provoking, dreadful, yet somehow bittersweet. Nevertheless, it will still make you question your own life, your mind and believes. I really love when horror games do this, instead of infinite jump-scares right at your face (which ngl is effective at first, but wears down very fast afterwards), the concept of the horror itself lingers in your mind for days, weeks, or heck, maybe the rest of your life. The [b]Psychological Horror[/b] is what makes SOMA so special.

[b]Just one single nip-pick tho...[/b]

The only problem I have with the game is that the gameplay is a bit lacking, like the whole game is basically just hiding / running away from monsters. Well I mean technically, we did get some intractable items to distract enemies, though it's only useful to some extent ([spoiler]like when we got to the sound-based monsters, Akers and Proxies[/spoiler]). But I really appreciate the monster designs, each and every one of them looked and act very distinctively, yet are all equally disgusting and terrifying. I just wish some of the monsters could stay and chase the player a bit longer, just to make the game a tad bit more challenging, especially towards the end ([spoiler]like the swimsuit monster, Jin Yoshida had a great entrance, my mind basically went from 0 to 100 the moment the door opened and reveal this new entity, but turns out it took me like 2 mins to complete that section and never saw him again[/spoiler]). It feels like the difficulty curve has stagnated during the last third of the game ([spoiler]i.e. after the Akers and Proxies[/spoiler]), which is a bit underwhelming tbh.
But hey, I understand that implementing more complicated gameplay mechanics or harder enemies would probably distract us from the master-class story it delivered, so I'd say the game did its job good enough.

Overall, despite the small gameplay variety problem, SOMA's immersive atmosphere and terrifying story is what make me, and many others sold on the game. This game's development team honestly deserves every single praise, just phenomenal!

134849069.review: I played this for the first time a year ago, haven't touched it since. I am STILL haunted by this game, and think of it regularly. Truly truly truly one of the absolute best horror games to have ever been made, hands down. The one caveat to recommending this is that it requires the player to thoughtfully engage with the story and its themes, though I suspect if you're even entertaining this game that shouldn't be an issue. Also, and I do mean this, be cautious playing this if you're experiencing or are prone to depression and/or existential crises. This game is unrelenting with its themes and when engaged with properly it hits HARD! Cannot recommend this highly enough. 10/10. The ending will follow me to my deathbed, no exaggeration.

134839445.review:
This game is incredible. One of my favorites.

It's a horror game with the standard terrifying monsters hunting you, which is done... okay? You're given breaks in between these sequences with both puzzles and exploration of the ruins of PATHOS-II, where you can slowly unveil what happened through text and audio logs. There are sections where you need to evade somewhat exploitable monster AI, though I still liked the atmosphere and ambiance. There is a "safe mode" you can use to avoid the whole monster thing.

But the best part of the game is the story, which it heavily focuses on throughout the game. It's even woven into the gameplay with constant necessary moral choices. I won't go into detail, because if you haven't played the game, you really should play it completely blind. Unfortunately, I had spoilers, but even then, the exploration of consciousness and existentialism has stuck with me for years, before I even finished the game. It's something I think about at night when I can't sleep. That is the real horror -- the horror that goes beyond the scary monsters.

I strongly recommend this game if you are a fan of undersea horror, story driven gameplay, or want an existential crisis that drives you into the depths of despair. Or you just want to be sad. Actually, I just recommend this game in general.

134810364.review: As someone who tries to avoid the walking simulator genre due to personal preferences, SOMA has completely and utterly blown me away with its breathtaking setting and thought-provoking story. Even though the gameplay comprises mainly of walking and exploring, it gets done through what I consider to be some of the most atmosphere-rich levels I think I've ever seen, with the occasional light environmental puzzles and survival horror mixed in. I'd also like to take a moment to recognize the excellent performance of Jared Zeus and Nell Mooney, the two leading actors who portray the main characters of Simon and Catherine. When it's just you surviving against the overwhelming odds, it's  vital to maintain a human connection, and their relationship quickly became one of my favorites. Regarding the best character duos in video games, they deserve to be up there with the likes of Booker and Elizabeth, Lee and Clementine, and Joel and Ellie. In the end, Soma was everything I thought it couldn't be and more, and I can't say enough good things about it. It was an experience that shattered my expectations and forced me to rethink what games in this genre are truly capable of, and as it stands, it might just very well be the best. Frictional Games had created a masterpiece in SOMA.

134609547.review:
First of all, no spoilers btw but this game's ending is VERY bleak, so if you suffer with depression at all, be careful playing this. And I mean this. I usually don't care about trigger warnings but this one I feel is very warranted. 

There are two different stories being told. The very simple not very scary surface story, and then the actually existentially terrifying, real story between the lines of everything. This game relishes is atmosphere and subtly, through environmental story telling, audio logs, emails, and the brilliance of the voice actors. 

The gameplay is fairly light with basically no combat, a few puzzles most of which are pretty easy but one in particular I remember being quite difficult but in a good way. There are only a few enemies in the game that only exist in certain parts of certain levels, but they all have unique ways of dealing with them. This isn't a survival horror game like Dead Space, or RE, with ammo and health drops all over, fighting hordes of zombies. There's no guns. There's no inventory. You only have a few items on you at any given time and they're either your omnitool (door opener primarily) or things used for the puzzles.

The real star of this game are the choices you have to make. Not dialogue choices, like in an RPG or choices of what path to go down. This game is as linear as you can get. By choices I mean actually morally gray choices about humanity, what it means to be human, what counts as a human experience, and things like this. Different choices don't change the outcome of the level or anything, but rather how you feel about what you had to do in order to progress to the next level. Also this game's story could only work as a video game because of this. Watching a character in a movie do these things doesn't have the same weight as you the player, with agency, doing these morally questionable things in order to complete the greater goal for humanity.

Minor context-less spoliers maybe for this next one.  





There also isn't really a villain in this story. It's simply technology doing exactly what we programmed it to do, and getting way out of hand. Such as AI being tasked with keeping humanity alive. Which might sound like a good idea, until you realize that there are things worse then death, and in certain situations, being kept alive is the worse possible outcome.

134396957.review:
Features an amazing sci-fi story that makes one think about the nature of existence, identity and what it means to be 'human'. That seems cliche to say, like there are many other movies and games that have this same theming, but I'll contest that this is the absolute best one. The topic shapes every memorable moment of the game. It is refreshing to see the topic explored so thoughtfully and expressed in such a beautiful way.

The gameplay is mostly stealth interspersed with puzzles and story. When enemies are anywhere near you will see static on the screen. They will not kill you instantly, but I think at most I ever took was 3 hits before dying or healing. It's not the most impressive to me in regards to gameplay, but I think this is effective to making the kind of horror they are going for. However I think it's worth saying that some people will be deterred by this system. Really it's fine, it works and didn't bother me much to have to start from a checkpoint. If you really hate it though there is an Easy mode that turns off deaths. The only problem is you might never bother learning how to get past each enemy and as a result not see the fun in it or even worse get frustrated by brute forcing.

I guess I could nitpick. The checkpoint system is event based and made repeating a couple areas frustrating when I die, the sneaking forces you to be slow sometimes when you do play it how it wants. Yeah, but as I said, nitpicks. Nothing that deterred me from very much enjoying the game.

This game has great story-telling, immersive isolation, grand sights and various fun puzzles. Even figuring out how to get by new enemies and even just looking around at all the details and creatures was fun. Very easy to enjoy if you're a fan of science fiction or stealth horror.

134280058.review:
I liked the game, but this is one of those games that I would've liked a lot more if it were a bit more of a walking simulator, even if that is a curseword these days. 

The bad:
Few times the game stopped me from exploring in peace with enemies that are relentlessly patrolling everything and my frustration was immense when I lured an enemy into a sci-fi equivalent of a broom closet and the bastard just opened the door after I closed it behind them. There was an immense feeling of developers not accepting my solution to dealing with an obstacle. Towards the end of the game you simply get worse encounters with either more enemies, or enemies that actively go after you with a knowledge of where you are so you're left with running around corridors and the instant kill mechanic if they catch you gets a tad stale fast.

The good:
The narrative of the game is pretty great and it poses great existential dilemmas and psychological conundrums and as an added bonus, I didn't have to use a walkthrough even once. Nothing is really missable in the game achievements-wise, which makes this one of the rare games that I've 100%'d. The game is just short enough to play through in a few sittings or one if you've really got nothing set up for a day.

Overall, I give this game a solid 8/10 despite a few glaring things that detracted from the experience along the way.

134275443.review:
I couldn't remember why I hadn't played SOMA for more than an hour when I first purchased it, so I installed recently and re-played the first few hours.  Now I know - SOMA is either a game you love, or hate...  and in my case it landed in the realm of hate.

It is at it's core, an outstanding story that employs some very bad mechanics, and abysmal "enemies".  I recommend playing in the story mode instead of normal for the best experience.  Even then it basically turns it into a walking simulator with brief puzzle elements, that gives you very little guidance or hints.

It wants badly to be a horror game, but it really isn't.  Instead it settles for a creepy atmosphere at best.

There are some very good critiques out on YouTube that explain what it does right, and the many things it does wrong.  If you're interested in more than a brief review with a thumbs up or down, go take a look and check one or more out.  I don't want to ruin any of the story in this review, since it's the only part of SOMA worth experiencing.

I can't think of anyone I'd recommend SOMA to at this point, since it really misses the mark on so many things.  Perhaps if you have endless time and patience available, and get the game at a ridiculously low price.  It might have been exceptionally stellar as just a digital novel but they tried to do more with it, and those things just destroy the game as a whole.

133678126.review:
[h1] Bravery Can Open Many Dark Secrets [/h1]

Soma takes place on an underwater remote research facility containing machinery that exhibits human characteristics, such as consciousness. Simon Jarrett, a fish-out-of-water protagonist, finds himself there under mysterious circumstances and embarks upon discovering its history, while trying to make sense of his predicament and potential future.

[table]
    [tr]
        [th]About[/th]
        [th]Description[/th]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]💾Graphics[/td]
        [td]SOMA has some of the best atmosphere I have seen. The lighting is superb even for today. The level design is next level and gives every area its own story. The creature design is top tier and fits the game perfectly. Also the atmosphere gives you a heavy feeling of dread and despair. If I had to nitpick, I would say that being inures kinda blurs that screen which can be pretty annoying, but besides that the graphics are top tier in my opinion.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🎮Gameplay[/td]
        [td]SOMA has pretty simple gameplay mechanics. You can interact with many objects, giving a great immersive experience for the player. There is no combat in this game, which some may not like, but it fits the game perfectly. The puzzles are pretty simple and don't halt the gameplay or pace in any way. The level design is very simple so pretty much impossible to get lost, but you must pay attention as you won’t get an objective marker in this game. Being attacked doesn’t really feel punishing in this game. It will take three to two knowdowns to kill you, even then the checkpoints are pretty frequent and you will rarely die. The game is pretty easy, with little to no challenge in my opinion. It’s not a bad thing since this game a story focused, but if you are looking for a challenge, you won’t get it here.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]📜Story[/td]
        [td]This is where the game truly shines. SOMA has such a unique and engaging story. Probably one of the better horror game stories I have played yet. It’s sad, mysterious, and dark. It does everything so well in terms of storytelling. I would say if you want to experience true story telling, you have to pick this game up. It’s so incredible in every way. It never gets dull and the pacing is perfect. Simon is such a well constructed protagonist. He’s relatable, and you can feel the pressure he is in. The desperation and sadness he presents really adds to the experience. The story is just so incredible in every way and I'm so happy I got to experience this game.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🕛Playtime[/td]
        [td]The main story was around 15+ hours of playtime for me. I did explore around and take my time so it may take less time for you to complete. It’s a good length story so you will not be disappointed.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🎧Sound[/td]
        [td]All from the music to the voice acting, the sound design is absolutely exceptional. The music fits the game so well. The voice acting is superb and realistic. You can hear and feel the anger and sadness the protagonist gives out. It’s so well done and I couldn't find any bad scenes from him. The music is truly haunting and fits the game perfectly. The monsters sound really scary, and the areas you explore make some really creepy noises that keep you on edge. It’s all so well thought out and I'm really impressed with it![/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]❗Bugs❗[/td]
        [td]I haven’t really experienced any issues with this game in terms of bugs. Everything was good and nothing was wrong with this game from my experience.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🔅Performance[/td]
        [td]for like 95% of the game it ran perfectly. No issues at all. But by the end I had some minor dips that would come right back up to 60fps again. Not sure if it’s a bug or just optimization (or my computer). Besides that minor issue, the game was smooth throughout my experience.[/td]
    [/tr]

[*]Superb voice acting
[*]Amazing lighting

[*]Interactable items

[/list]
[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]

[/list]
[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🏆Rating[/td]
        [td]9/10
Despite the game being great, $30 is too much in my opinion. Try getting this game for around 25-50% off.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🔗Conclusion[/td]
        [td]SOMA is a unique horror game in its own right. The story is a one of a kind experience in my opinion. The acting is some of the best out there, and the fear this game can present is incredible. If you are a fan of horror games or just looking to dip your toes into the horror scene, this is a must buy. This game may provide no challenge, but the story is what makes SOMA stand out of many horror games. Give this game a shot, it’s worth your time no question! A true treat for everyone![/td]

133265197.review:
SOMA took a while to grow on me, but when it did... holy shit. A truly brain-bending concept executed in a brilliant manner. What irritated me initially were the significant resemblances to other classic games, such as Dead Space and BioShock, but eventually SOMA found its own character and became a deeply immersive experience. In many ways the exploration of the underwater base (and open seafloor) was very realistic, and always immersed in a thick and tense atmosphere, created by the world and character design, music, sound, and charismatic and convincing voice acting. It could be better visually (which I guess is down to the relatively small team behind it), but that didn't prevent it from providing some of the most intense and profound moments I've ever experienced in a game.

A definite must-play.

133261157.review:
I'd watched Let's Plays of this game years ago, but hosts either didn't fully explore the environment or they played/talked like they had severe ADHD. After seeing that a Safe Mode was added during an eye-catching 90%-off sale recently, I snagged it.

As far as the game goes, it has most of your usual Frictional mechanics: "manually" opening and closing doors and drawers, minor puzzles, stealth, and avoiding eye contact with disfigured monsters lest they insta-kill or occasionally mercifully just KO you. However, there's a much tighter focus on storytelling here...more Penumbra than Amnesia, if you will. While the thought experiments aren't exactly new, the narrative still provides plenty of fodder for philosophical reflection or discussion, even if you have a more faith-based view of what constitutes humanity and eternity. I strongly suggest playing the game blind first, then doing a second playthrough after reading the wiki and additional canon text and videos provided by the devs before the game's release.

[u]To clarify Safe Mode[/u]: Monsters still react to your presence, but are generally unable to actually attack. As such, they can still be pretty intense if you feign playing normally. Note that there is one unavoidable scripted attack, and there was a late-game enemy that did hit me, though no damage appears to have been caused.

Note that the nudity tag on the game refers to barely discernible genitalia on some enemies which you won't ever see in normal circumstances.

[h1]The Good[/h1]
+Great ambience
+Voice actors are really good
+Each enemy has different AI
+Safe Mode lets you explore for story with little threat
+Great story. Multiple playthroughs add so many eureka moments.
+Lots of philosophical consideration and related choices
+Save anywhere, plus periodic autosaves
+Loading screen has objective reminders
+Minor puzzles
+Couple very well hidden, but not immersion-breaking easter eggs
+8-12 hours long, depending on play style
+One short splash screen for Frictional. [b]I can't stress enough how nice it is to open a game and get right to the main menu[/b]. No unskippable parade of cutscenes for every included development module. No warnings that video games contain flashing lights or that fire is hot. No notes that a team of multicultural yuppies made sure millennials weren't butthurt during the making of the game.

[h1]YMMV[/h1]
~Foul language (though I'd likely be losing my sh-t too)
~Contains dismembered corpses and body horror, but no animated violent deaths
~Jumpscares, mostly from douchebag lightbulbs
~Not for the thalassophobic
~Other than the stealth/horror sections, it's a walking sim
~Only one save slot
~Easy to miss a few bits of recorded dialog
~Lengthy bit of texure popping after loading a game
~Main character definitely has faults...but I guess that makes him more real

[h1]The Bad[/h1]
-A few areas very hard to fully explore without Safe Mode

133036087.review:
Hmmm... Not sure why this is billed as a survival horror game. There's not really anything to survive, and very little in the way of horror or even tension - I came across a couple of 'enemies' but just walked past them. Indeed, if I'm being honest, there isn't much 'game.' 

It feels like a successor to the point and click adventures of the yesteryear, just without the puzzles. Or possibly to the FMV games of the 90s. You basically walk down a long corridor / tunnel / stretch of sea bed, find the thing you're supposed to click, and get another bit of exposition. And then you're on to the next corridor / tunnel / stretch of sea bed to find the next thing to click and get a bit more of the story. 

As other reviews have suggested, maybe it's better viewed as an interactive novel. It's just that, while it's got some interesting themes and decent writing, there's not *that* much there. It's padded out with an awful lot walking but, if you strip that out, you've got a short story at most; not really enough even for a novella. 
 
Overall, I found myself struggling to remain engaged with it, got about half way through and just googled a summary of the plot. I can't help think it might have been better done as a graphic novel. Ps - If you're really invested, there's collections of the various cut scenes on youtube. It saves a lot of walking...

132818032.review:
An existential crisis.

I didn't think I'd enjoy this game. I religiously avoid anything with a [i]horror[/i] tag, so this has gathered dust in my library for [i]years[/i].

But...I'm glad I played it. SOMA is a tale of personal discovery, a story of overcoming adversity, and a journey of partners struggling across a finish line with no celebration on the other side. SOMA will test your mind in ways that were unique in my limited experience. Besides boundless tension, a perpetual sense of dread, and utter nightmare fuel for any submechanophobes, SOMA's true horror lies in its narrative. SOMA will question your humanity, present decisions which make up your mind, then questions it again and again ad nauseum until you've no will left to decide. While you wrestle with your own sense of self, SOMA leaves [i]dozens[/i] of set-pieces and story bites for you to collect. Each adds depth to the environment, a heft to the story, and a sense of helplessness as you watch over corpses while the story of their demise unfolds.

If the setting doesn't add enough tension for you, the "monsters" certainly will. These enemies are divisive. On one hand, you have an external force pushing you through a level - transforming a simple exploration into a delicate stealth operation. On the other hand, how much value did that add to the game? Though the fear dissipates quickly once you understand how they work, that initial scare stays with you. It makes every new encounter more threatening, each dialogue reference more damning. A face to a necessary evil with a name.

This entire game is a well-orchestrated tragedy whose only resolution is what [i]you[/i] think it should be. Dialogue will end with a period, but the story ends with a question mark. I wince like a baby just [i]watching[/i] most horror games, but SOMA is a master class in a thought-provoking and discomforting way.

Well done, Frictional.
